editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The antipodes: a comedy. Acted in the year 1638. by the Queen's majesty's servants, at Salisbury court in Fleetstreet.
London: printed by I. Okes, for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shops in Kings-street at the sign of the goat, and in Westminster-hall. 1640.

div.head: To the right honourable William Earl of Hertford, etc.
div.p:
The long experience, I have had of your honour's favourable intentions towards me, hath compelled me to this presumption. But I hope your goodness will be pleased to pardon what your benignity was the cause of, viz. the error of my dedication. Had your candour not encouraged me, in this I had been innocent: yet (I beseech you) think not, I intend it any other, than your recreation at your retirement from your
weighty employments; and to be the declaration of your gracious encouragements towards me, and the testimony of my gratitude. If the public view of the world entertain it with no less welcome, then that private one of the stage already has given it, I shall be glad the world owes you the thanks: if it meet with too severe construction, I hope your protection. What hazards soever it shall justle with, my desires are it may pleasure your lordship in the perusal, which is the only ambition he is conscious of, who is

closer.signed: Your honour's humbly devoted: Richard Brome.

div.head: To censuring critics, on the approved comedy, the antipodes.
div.l: Jonson's alive! the world admiring stands,
And to declare his welcome there, shake hands;
Apollo's pensioners may wipe their eyes,
And stifle their abortive elegies:
Taylor his goose-quill may abjure again,
And to make paper dear, scribbling refrain;
For sure there's cause of neither. Jonson's ghost
Is not a tenant i' the Elysian coast:
But vexed with too much scorn, at your dispraise,
Silently stole unto a grove of bays;
Therefore bewail your errors, and entreat
He will return, unto the former seat,
Whence he was often pleased, to feed your ear
With the choice dainties of his theatre;
But I much fear, he'll not be easily won
To leave his bower, where grief, and he alone
Do spend their time, to see how vainly we
Accept old toys, for a new comedy.
Therefore repair to him, and praise each line
Of his Volpone, Sejanus, Catiline.
But stay, and let me tell you, where he is,
He sojourns in his Brome's antipodes.

lg.l: Opinion, which our author cannot court,
(For the dear daintiness of it) has, of late,
From the old way of plays possessed a sort
Only to run to those, that carry state
In scene magnificent and language high;
And clothes worth all the rest, except the action.
And such are only good those leaders cry;
And into that belief draw on a faction,
That must despise all sportive, merry wit,
Because some such great play had none in it.
But it is known (Peace to their memories)
The poets late sublimed from our age,
Who best could understand, and best device
Works, that must ever live upon the stage,
Did well approve, and lead this humble way,
Which we are bound to travail in tonight ;
And, though it be not traced so well, as they
Discovered it by true Phoebean light,
Pardon our just ambition, yet that strive
To keep the weakest branch o'th' stage alive.
I mean the weakest in their great esteem,
That count all slight, that's under us, or nigh;
And only those for worthy subjects deem,
Fetched, or reached at (At least) from far, or high:
When low and homebred subjects have their use,
As well, as those, fetched from on high, or far;
And 'tis as hard a labour for the muse
To move the earth, as to dislodge a star.
See, yet, those glorious plays; and let their sight
Your admiration move; these your delight.

div.head: To the author on his comedy, the antipodes.
div.l: Steered, by the hand of fate, o'er swelling seas,
Methought I landed on th' antipodes;
Where I was straight a stranger: for 'tis thus,
Their feet do tread against the tread of us.
My scull mistook: thy book, being in my hand,
Hurried my soul to th' Antipodian strand,
Where I did feast my fancy, and mine eyes
With such variety of rarities,
That I perceive thy muse frequents some shade,
Might be a grove for a pierian maid.
Let idiots prate; it boots not what they say.
Th' antipodes to wit and learning may
Have ample privilege: for among that crew,
I know there's not a man can judge of you.

list.item: Byplay, a conceited servant to Letoy.
Trulocke, a close friend to Letoy.
Followers of the lord Letoyes, who are actors in the byplay.

sp.l: To me, and to the city, sir, you are welcome,
And so are all about you: we have long
Suffered in want of such fair company.
But now that times calamity has given way
(Thanks to high providence) to your kinder visits,
We are (Like half pined wretches, that have lain
Long on the planks of sorrow, strictly tied
To a forced abstinence, from the sight of friends)
The sweetlier filled with joy.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Alas, I bring
Sorrow too much with me to fill one house,
In the sad number of my family.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Be comforted good sir, my house, which now
You may be pleased to call your own, is large
Enough to hold you all; and for your sorrows,
you came to lose 'em: and I hope the means
Is readily at hand: the doctor's coming,
Who, as by letters, I advertised you,
Is the most promising man to cure your son,
The kingdom yields; it will astonish you
To hear the marvels he hath done in cures
Of such distracted ones, as is your son,
And not so much by bodily physic (No!
He sends few recipes to th' apothecaries)
As medicine of the mind, which he infuses
So skilfully, yet by familiar ways,
That it begets both wonder and delight
In his observers, while the stupid patient
Finds health at unawares.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You speak well of him:
Yet I may fear, my sons long grown disease
Is such he hath not met with.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Then I'll tell you sir,
He cured a country gentleman, that fell mad
For spending of his land before he sold it:
That is, 'twas sold to pay his debts: all went
That way, for a dead horse, as one would say,
He had not money left to buy his dinner,
Upon that wholesale day. This was a cause,
Might make a gentleman mad you'll say; and him
It did, as mad as land less squire could be.
This doctor by his art removed his madness,
And mingled so much wit among his brains,
That, by the overflowing of it merely,
He gets and spends five hundred pound a year now,
As merrily as any gentleman
In Derbyshire; I name no man. But this
Was pretty well you'll say.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: My son's disease
Grows not that way.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: There was a lady mad,
I name no lady: but stark mad she was,
As any in the country, city, or almost
In court could be.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: With study;
Tedious and painful study: and for what
Now can you think?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: For painting, or new fashions.
I cannot think for the philosopher's stone.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: No, 'twas to find a way to love her husband,
Because she did not, and her friends rebuked her.

sp.speaker: Ioy
sp.p: Was that so hard to find, if she desired it.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: She was seven years in search of it, and could not,
Though she consumed his whole estate by it.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: No; he was not born
With wit enough to lose, but mad was she
Until this doctor took her into cure,
And now she lies as lovingly on a flockbed
With her own knight, as she had done on down ▪
With many others, but I name no parties,
Yet this was well you'll say.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Then sir, of officers, and men of place,
Whose senses were so numbed, they understood not
Bribes from due fees, and fell on premunires,
He has cured divers, that can now distinguish,
And know both when, and how to take, of both;
And grow most safely rich by't, tother day
He set the brains of an attorney right,
That were quite topsy-turvy overturned
In a pitch o'er the bar; so that (Poor man)
For many moons, he knew not whether he
Went on his heels or's head, till he was brought
To this rare doctor, now he walks again,
As upright in his calling, as the boldest
Amongst 'em. This was well you'll say.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: And then for horn mad citizens my neighbours,
He cures them by the dozens, and we live
As gently with our wives, as rams with ewes.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: We do you say, were you one of his patients.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: 'Slid he has almost catched me; no sir no,
I name no parties I, but wish you merry;
I strain to make you so, and could tell forty
Notable cures of his to pass the time
Until he comes.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: But pray, has he the art
To cure a husband's jealousy?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Mine sir he did: 'sfoot I am caught again.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: But still you name no party, pray how long,
Good master blaze, has this so famous doctor
Whom you so well set out, been a professor?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Never in public: nor endures the name
Of doctor, though I call him so, but lives
With an odd lord in town, that looks like no lord,
My doctor goes more like a lord than he. Ex. doctor.
O welcome sir, I sent mine own wife for you:
Ha you brought her home again?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: She's in your house,
With gentlewomen, who seem to lodge here.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes sir, this gentleman's wife, and his son's wife:
They all ail something, but his son ('tis thought)
Is falling into madness, and is brought
Up by his careful father to the town here
To be your patient, speak with him about it.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: How do you find him sir? does his disease
Take him by fits; or is it constantly,
And at all times the same?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: For the most part
It is only inclining still to worse,
As he grows more in days; by all the best
Conjectures we have met with in the country,
'Tis found a most deep melancholy.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Was it born with him? is it natural,
Or accidental? have you or his mother
Been so at any time affected?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Never,
not she unto her grave; nor I, till then,
Knew what a sadness meant; though since, I have
In my son's sad condition, and some crosses
In my late marriage, which at further time
I may acquaint you with.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: The old man's jealous
Of his young wife; I find him by the question
He put me to ere while.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Divers years since; for we had hope a wife
Might have restrained his travelling thoughts, and so
Have been a means to cure him; but it failed us.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: What has he in his younger years been most
Addicted to? what study? or what practice?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You have now, sir, found the question, which I think
Will lead you to the ground of his distemper.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: That's the next way to the cure. Come quickly, quickly ▪

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: In tender years he always loved to read
Reports of travails, and of voyages;
And when young boys, like him, would tire themselves
With sports, and pastimes, and restore their spirits
Again by meat and sleep; he would whole days
And nights (Sometimes by stealth) be on such books
As might convey his fancy round the world.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: When he grew up towards twenty,
His mind was all on fire to be abroad;
Nothing but travail still was all his aim;
There was no voyage or foreign expedition
Be said to be in hand, but he made suit
To be made one in it his mother and
Myself opposed him still in all, and strongly
Against his will, still held him in; and won
Him into marriage; hoping that would call
In his extravagant thoughts, but all prevailed not,
Nor stayed him (Though at home) from travailing
So far beyond himself, that now too late,
I wish he had gone abroad to meet his fate.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Well sir, upon good terms I'll undertake
your son: let's see him.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yet there's more: his wife sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I'll undertake her too. Is she mad too?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Alas the danger is they will have none,
He takes no joy in her; and she no comfort
In him: for though they have been three years wed,
They are yet ignorant of the marriage bed,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I shall find her the madder of the two then.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Indeed she's full of passion, which she utters
By the effects, as diversely, as several
Objects reflect upon her wand'ring fancy,
Sometimes in extreme weepings, and anon
In vehement laughter; now in sullen silence,
And presently in loudest exclamations.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Come let me see 'em sir, I'll undertake
Her too: ha' you any more? how does your wife?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I'll undertake
Her too: and you yourself sir (By your favour ▪
And some few yellow spots, which I perceive
About your temples) may require some council.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: But my son, my son sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: There's news too much within,
For any homebred Christian understanding.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, pray doctor Hughball
Play the man-midwife, and deliver him
Of his huge timpany of news; of monsters,
Pigmies, and giants, apes, and elephants,
Griffons, and crocodiles; men upon women,
And women upon men; the strangest doings
As far beyond all Christendom, as 'tis to't.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Beyond the moon and stars I think,
Or mount in Cornwall either.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: How prettily like a fool she talks?
And she were not mine own wife, I could be
So taken with her.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He talks much of the kingdom of Cathaya,
Of one great khan, and goodman Prester John,
( whate'er they be) and says that caan's a clown
Unto the John he speaks of ▪ and that John
Dwells up almost at paradise: but sure his mind
Is in a wilderness : for there he says
Are geese that have two heads a piece, and hens
That bear more wool upon their backs than sheep.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: O Mandevile, let's to him lead the way sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And men with heads like hounds.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You'll find enough within I warrant ye. Ex. 3.
And here comes the poor mad gentleman's wife,Ent. Mar.
Almost as mad as he: she haunts me all
About the house to impart something to me:
Poor heart I guess her grief, and pity her.
To keep a maidenhead three years after marriage,
Under wedlock and key, insufferable! monstrous,
It turns into a wolf within the flesh,
Not to be fed with chickens, and tame pigeons.
I could wish maids be warned by't, not to marry
Before they have wit to lose their maidenheads,
For fear they match with men whose wits are passed it.
What a sad look, and what a sigh was there?
Sweet mistress joyless, how is't with you now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: When i shall know I'll tell, pray tell me first,
How long have you been married?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Now she is on it. Three years forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And truly so have i, we shall agree i see.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No woman merrier, now i have met with one
Of my condition. Three years married say you, ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Three years married, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis just my story. And you have had no child,
That's still my story, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Nay I have had two children.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are you sure on't,
Or does your husband only tell you so,
Take heed o'that, for husbands are deceitful.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But I am o'the surer side, I am sure
I groaned for mine and bore 'em. when at best,
He but believes he got'em .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yet both he
And you may be deceived, for now I'll tell you,
My husband told me, faced me down and stood on't,
We had three sons, and all great travellers,
That one had shaken the great Turk by the beard,
I never saw 'em, nor am I such a fool
To think that children can be got and born,
Trained up to men, and then sent out to travel,
And the poor mother never know nor feel
Any such matter; there's a dream indeed.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now you speak reason, and 'tis nothing but
Your husband's madness that would put that dream
Into you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He may put dreams into me, but
He ne'er put child nor any thing towards it yet
To me to making: something sure belongsWeep.
To such a work for I am passed a child
Myself to think they are found in parsley beds,
Strawberry banks or rosemary bushes, though
I must confess I have sought and searched such places,
Because I would fain have had one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray tell me, for I think nobody hears us,
How came you by your babes? I cannot think
Your husband got them you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fool did I say?
She is a witch I think: why not my husband,
pray can you charge me with another man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor with him neither, be not angry pray now.
For were I now to die, I cannot guess
What a man does in child-getting, I remember
A wanton maid once lay with me, and kissed
And clipped, and clapped me strangely, and then wished
That I had been a man to have got her with child:
What must I then ha' done, or (Good now tell me)
What has your husband done to you?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Was ever
Such a poor piece of innocence, three years married?
Does not your husband use to lie with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes he does use to lie with me, but he does not
Lie with me to use me as she should i fear,
Nor do I know to teach him, will you tell me,
I'll lie with you and practise if you please.
Pray take me for a night or two: or take
My husband and instruct him, but one night,
Our country folks will say, you London wives
Do not lie every night with your own husbands.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your country folks should have done well to ha' sent
Some news by you, but I trust none told you there,
We use to leave our fools to lie with madmen.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No not I
But rather pity your simplicity.
Come I'll take charge and care of you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And wage my skill, against my doctor's art,
Sooner to ease you of these dangerous fits,
Than he shall rectify your husband's wits. Ex.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Why broughtest thou not mine arms, and pedigree
Home with thee blaze, mine honest heralds, painter?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I have not yet my lord, but all's in readiness,
According to the herald's full directions.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: But has he gone to the root, has he derived me,
Ex origine, ab antiquo? has he fetched me
far enough blaze?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Full four descents beyond
The conquest my good lord, and finds that one
Of your French ancestry came in with the conqueror.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Jefrey Letoy, 'twas he, from whom the English
Letoy's have our descent; and here have taken
Such footing, that we'll never out while France
Is France, and England England,
And the sea passable to transport a fashion.
My ancestors and I have been beginners
Of all new fashions in the court of England
From before primo Ricardi secundi
Until this day.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I cannot think my lord
They'll follow you in this though.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Mark the end,
I am without a precedent for my humour.
But is it spread, and talked of in the town?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: It is my lord, and laughed at by a many.
I am more beholding to them, than all the rest:
Their laughter makes me merry; others mirth,
And not mine own it is, that feeds me that
Battens me as poor men's cost does usurers.
But tell me blaze, what say they of me, ha?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: They say my lord you look more like a pedlar,
Then like a lord, and live more like an emperor.

sp.speaker: Let
sp.l: Why there they ha' me right, let others shine
Abroad in cloth of bodkin, my broad cloth,
Pleases mine eye as well, my body better,
Besides I'm sure 'tis paid for (To their envy)
I buy with ready money: and at home here
With as good meat, as much magnificence,
As costly pleasures, and as rare delights,
Can satisfy my appetite and senses,
As they with all their public shows, and braveries.
They run at ring, and tilt 'gainst one another,
I and my men can play a match at football,
Wrestle a handsome fall, and pitch the bar,
And crack the cudgels, and a pate sometimes,
'twould do you good to see't.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: They hunt the deer, the hare, the fox, the otter,
Polecats, or harlots, what they please, whilst I
And my mad grigs, my men can run at base,
And breathe ourselves at barleybreak, and dancing.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes my lord i'th country when you are there.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And now I am here i'th city, sir, I hope
I please myself with more choice home delights,
Than most men of my rank.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I know my lord
Your house in substance is an amphitheatre
Of exercise and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Sir, I have
For exercises, fencing, dancing, vaulting,
And for delight, music of all best kinds:
Stageplays, and masques, are nightly my pastimes.
And all within myself. My own men are
My music, and my actors. I keep not
A man or boy but is of quality:
The worst can sing or play his part o'th' viols,
And act his part too in a comedy,
For which I lay my bravery on their backs;
And where another lord undoes his followers,
I maintain mine like lords. And there's my bravery.
sp.stage: Hoboys. A service as for dinner, pass over the stage, born by many servitors richly apparelled, doing honour to letoy as they pass. Ex.
sp.l: Now tell me blaze, look these like pedlars men?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I tell thee,
These lads can act the emperor's lives all over,
And Shakespeare's chronicled histories, to boot,
And were that Caesar, or that English Earl,
That loved a play and player so well now living,
I would not be outvied in my delights.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I love the quality of playing I, i love a play withal
My heart, a good one; and a player that is
a good one too, with all my heart: as for the poets,
No men love them, I think, and therefore
I write all my plays myself, and make no doubt
Some of the court will follow
Me in that too. Let my fine lords
Talk of their horse-tricks, and their jockeys, that
Can out-talk them. Let the gallants boast
Their may-games, play-games, and their mistresses,
I love a play in my plain clothes, ay,
And laugh upon the actors in their brave ones. Ent. Quailp.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.p: My lord, your dinner stays prepared.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well, well,
Be you as ready with your grace as IEx. Quail.
Am for my meat, and all is well. Blaze we have rambled
From the main point this while, it seems by his letter,
My doctor's busy at thy house. I know who's there,
Beside, give him this ring, tell him it wants
A finger: farewell good blaze.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Tell him it wants a finger! My small wit,
Already finds what finger it must fit.

div.head: Act. 1. Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter doctor, Peregrine, a book in his hand, joyless, Diana

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sir I applaud your noble disposition,
And even adore the spirit of travail in you,
And purpose to wait on it through the world,
In which I shall but tread again the steps
I heretofore have gone.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: All the world o'er ha' you been already?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yes, through, and through:
No isle nor angle in that nether world,
But I have made discovery of: pray sir sit;
And sir be you attentive, I will warrant
His speedy cure without the help of Galen,
Hippocrates, Avicen, or Dioscorides,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: A rare man: husband, truly I like his person
As well as his rare skill.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Into your chamber.
I do not like your liking of men's persons.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Nay lady you may stay: hear and admire,
If you so please: but make no interruptions.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: And let no looser words, or wand'ring look
Bewray an intimation of the slight
Regard you bear your husband, lest I send you
Upon a further pilgrimage, than he
Feigns to convey my son.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Do you think sir, to th' antipodes such a journey?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I think there's none beyond it; and that Mandevile
Whose excellent work this is, was th' only man
That e'er came near it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Beyond all English legs that I can read of.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: What think you sir of drake, our famous countryman?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Drake was a didapper to Mandevile,
Candish, and Hawkins, Furbisher, all our voyagers
Went short of Mandevile: but had he reached
To this place here — yes here — this wilderness,
And seen the trees of the sun and moon, that speak,
And told King Alexander of his death, he then
Had left a passage open for travellers:
That now is kept and guarded by wild beasts,
Dragons, and serpents, elephants white and blue
Unicorns, and lions of many colours,
And monsters more, as numberless, as nameless.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Stay there,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Read here else: can you read?
Is it not true?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: No truer than I ha' seen't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Have you been there sir, ha' you seen those trees?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: And talked with 'em ▪ and tasted of their fruit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Read here again then: it is written here,
That you may live four or five hundred year.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Brought you none of that fruit home with you sir?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You would have some of't would you, to have hope
T'outlive your husband by't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Yed have't for you,
in hope you might outlive your jealousy.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Your patience both I pray; I know the grief
You both do labour with, and how to cure it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Would I had given you half my land 'twere done.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Would I had given him half my love, to settle
The tother half free from encumbrances
Upon my husband.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Do not think it strange sir:
I'll make your eyes witnesses of more
Than i relate, if you'll but travail with me ▪
You hear me not deny that all is true
That Mandevile delivers of his travails,
Yet i myself may be as well believed.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Since you speak reverently of him, say on.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Of Europe I'll not speak, 'tis too near home:
Who's not familiar with the Spanish garb,
Th'italian shrug, French cringe, and German hug?
Nor will i trouble you with my observations
Fetched from Arabia, Paphlagonia,
Mesopotamia, Mauritania,
Syria, Thessalia, Persia, India,
All still is too near home: though I have touched
The clouds upon the Pyrenaean mountains,
And been on Paphos isle, where I have kissed
The image of bright Venus: all is still
Too near home to be boasted.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That I like well in him too, he will not boast of kissing
A woman too near home.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: These things in me are poor: they found
In a far travellers care,
Like the reports of those, that beggingly
Have put out, on returns from Edinburgh,
Paris, or Venice, or perhaps Madrid,
Whither a milliner may with half a nose
Smell out his way: and is not ne'er so difficult,
As for some man in debt, and unprotect
To walk from Charing-cross to th'old exchange.
No, i will pitch no nearer than th' antipodes;
That which is farthest distant, foot to foot
against our region.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What with their heels upwards?
Bless us! how scape they breaking of their necks?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: They walk upon firm earth, as we do here,
And have the firmament over their heads,
As we have here

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And yet just under us!
Where is hell then? if they whose feet are towards us,
At the lower part of the world have heaven too
Beyond their heads, where's hell?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You may find that
Without inquiry: cease your idle questions.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Sure hell's above ground then in jealous husbands ▪

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What people sir (I pray proceed) what people
Are they of the antipodes? are they not such
As Mandevile writes of, without heads or necks,
Having their eyes placed on their shoulders, and
Their mouths amid their breasts?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Though heels go upwards, and their feet should slip,
They have no necks to break.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Silence sweet lady.
Pray give the gentleman leave to understand me.
The people through the whole world of antipodes,
In outward feature, language, and religion,
Resemble those to whom they are supposite:
They under Spain appear like Spaniards,
Under France Frenchmen, under England English
To the exterior show: but in their manners,
Their carriage, and condition of life
Extremely contrary. To come close to you,
What part of th' world's antipodes shall i now
Decipher to you, or would you travail to?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: That is th' antipodes of England.
The people there are contrary to us.
As thus; here (Heaven be praised) the magistrates
Govern the people: there the people rule
The magistrates.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: There's precious bribing then.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You'll hold your peace,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Nay lady 'tis by nature,
Here generally men govern the women.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: But there the women overrule the men,
If some men fail here in their power, some women
Slip their holds there. As parents here, and masters,
Command, there they obey the child and servant.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But pray sir, is't by nature or by art,
That wives o'ersway their husbands there?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Then art's above nature, as they are under us.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: In brief sir, all
Degrees of people both in sex, and quality,
Deport themselves in life and conversation,
Quite contrary to us.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why then the women
Do get the men with child ▪ and put the poor fools
To grievous pain I warrant you in bearing.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Into your chamber, get you in I charge you.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: By no means, as you tender your son's good.
No lady no; that were to make men women,
And women men. But there the maids do woe
The bachelors, and 'tis most probable,
The wives lie uppermost.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That is a trim
Upside-down Antipodian trick indeed.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And then at christenings and gossips feasts,
A woman is not seen, the men do all
The tittle-tattle duties, while the women
Hunt, hawk, and take their pleasure.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Have they good game I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Excellent,
But by the contraries to ours, for where
We hawk at pheasant, partridge, mallard, Heron,
With goshawk, Tarsell, falcon, Laneret;
Our hawks, become their game, our game their hawks,
and so the like in hunting. There the deer
Pursue the hounds, and (Which you may think strange)
I ha' seen one sheep worry a dozen foxes,
By moonshine; in a morning before day,
They hunt, trayne-sents with oxen, and blow with dogs.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Are not their swans all black, and ravens white?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yes indeed are they; and their parrots teach
Their mistresses to talk.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: They keep their cats in cages,
From mice that would devour them else; and birds
Teach 'em to whistle, and cry beware the rat's puss.
But these are frivolous nothings. I have known
Great ladies ride great horses run at tilt;
At ring, races, and hunting matches, while
Their lords at home have painted, pawned their plate
And jewels to feast their honourable servants.
And there the merchants wives do deal abroad
Beyond seas, while their husbands cuckold them
At home.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Then there are cuckolds too it seems,
As well as here.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: By hearsay sir. I am not wise enough
To speak it on my knowledge yet.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Patience good sir,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: What do you laugh, that there is cuckold-making
In the antipodes, I tell you sir,
It is not so abhorred here as 'tis held
In reputation there: all your old men
Do marry girls, and old women boys,
As generation were to be maintained
Only by cuckold making.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Pray your patience.
There's no such honest men there in their world,
as are their lawyers: they give away
Their practice; and t'enable 'em to do so,
Being all handy-crafts, or labouring men,
They work (Poor hearts full hard) in the vacations,
To give their law for nothing in the term times.
No fees are taken: which makes their divines,
Being generally covetous, the greatest wranglers
In law suits of a kingdom, you have not there
A gentleman in debt, though citizens
Haunt them with cap in hand to take their wares.
On credit.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: What fine sport would that be here now!

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: All wit and mirth and good society
Is there among the hirelings, clowns, and tradesmen,
And all their poets are Puritans.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And players too. But they are all the sobrest
Precisest people picked out of a nation.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: She must if you can hope for any cure,
Be governed sir: your jealousy will grow
A worse disease than your son's madness else,
You are content I take the course I told you of
To cure the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Say master Peregrine, will you travail now
With me to the antipodes, or has not
The journey wearied you in the description.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No I could hear you a whole fortnight, butA bowl on the table.
Let's lose no time, pray talk on as we pass.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: First, sir a health to auspicate our travails,
And we'll away.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Give me't. What's he? One sent

div.head: Act. 1. Scene. 7.
div.l: I fear from my dead mother, to make stop
Of our intended voyage.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: My lord, sir understands the course you're in,
by your letters he tells me; and bade me give you
This ring, which wants a finger here he says

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: No sir, he brings me word
The mariner calls away; the wind and tide
Are fair, and they are ready to weigh anchor,
Hoist sails, and only stay for us, pray drink sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A health then to the willing winds and seas,
And all that steer towards th' antipodes.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: He has not drunk so deep a draught this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: 'Tis a deep draught indeed, and now 'tis down,
And carries him down to the antipodes?
I mean but in a dream.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Alas I fear.
See he begins to sink.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Trust to my skill,
Pray take an arm, and see him in his cabin.
Good lady save my ring that's fallen there.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: In sooth a marvelous neat and costly one

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: So, so, the ring has found a finger.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Come sir, aboard, aboard, aboard, aboard.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: To bed, to bed, to bed: I know your voyage,
And my dear lords dear plot, I understand,
Whose ring hath passed here by your flight of hand.
Tonight sayest thou my Hughball?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: By all means,
And if your play takes to my expectation,
As I not doubt my potion works to yours,
Your fancy and my cure shall be cried up
Miraculous. O you're the lord of fancy.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I'm not ambitious of that title sir,
No, the Letoy's are of antiquity,
Ages before the fancies were begotten,
and shall beget still new to the world's end.
But are you confident of your potion doctor?
Sleeps the young man?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yes ▪ and has slept these twelve hours,
After a thousand mile an hour outright,
By sea and land; and shall awake anon
In the antipodes.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well sir my actors
Are all in readiness; and I think all perfect,
But one, that never will be perfect in a thing
He studies; yet he makes such shifts extempore,
(Knowing the purpose what he is to speak to)
That he moves mirth in me above all the rest.
For I am none of those poetic furies,
That threats the actor's life, in a whole play,
That adds a syllable, or takes away.
If he can fribble through, and move delight
In others, I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: It is that mimic fellow which your lordship
But lately entertained.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: He will be wondrous apt in my affair:
For I must take occasion to interchange,
Discourse with him sometimes amid their scenes,
T'inform my patient, my mad young travellor
In divers matters.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Do, put him to't: I use't myself sometimes.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I know it is your way.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well to the business.
Hast wrought the jealous gentleman, old joyless,
To suffer his wife to see our comedy.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: She brings your ring, my lord, upon her finger,
And he brings her in's hand. I have instructed her
To spur his jealousy of o'the legs.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: And I will help her in't.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: The young distracted
Gentlewoman too, that's sick of her virginity,
Yet knows not what it is; and blaze and's wife
Shall all be your guests tonight , and not alone
spectators, but (As we will carry it) actor
To fill your comic scenes with double mirth.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Go fetch 'em then, while I prepare my actors. Ex. Doc.
Within there ho?
sp.stage:
Within.
1 this is my beard and hair.
2 my lord appointed it for my part.
3 no, this is for you; and this is yours, this grey one.
4 where be the foils, and targets for the women?
1 here, can't you see?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: What a rude coil is there? But yet it pleases me.
sp.stage:
Within.
1 you must not wear that cloak and hat.
2 who told you so? I must.
sp.l: In my first scene, and you must wear that robe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: What a noise make those knaves? come in one of you:
Are you the first that answers to that name?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Why are not you ready yet?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I am not to put on my shape, before
I have spoke the prologue. And for that my lord
I yet want something.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: What I pray with your grave formality?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: I want my beaver-shoes, and leather-cap,
To speak the prologue in; which were appointed
By your lordship's own direction.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Well sir, well:
There they be for you; I must look to all.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Certes my lord, it is a most apt conceit:
The comedy being the world turned upside-down,
That the presenter wear the capital beaver
Upon his feet, and on his head shoe-leather.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Trouble not you your head with my conceit,
But mind your part let me not see you act now,
In your scholastic way, you brought to town with ye ▪
With see saw sack a down, like a sawyer;
Nor in a comic scene, play Hercules furens,
Tearing your throat to split the audients ears.
And you sir, you had got a trick of late,
Of holding out your bum in a set speech;
Your fingers fibulating on your breast,
as if your buttons, or your bandstrings were
Helps to your memory. Let me see you in't
No more I charge you. No, nor you sir, in
That over-action of the legs I told you of,
Your singles, and your doubles, look you — thus —
Like one o'th' dancing masters o'the bear-garden;
And when you have spoke, at end of every speech,
Not minding the reply, you turn you round
As tumblers do; when betwixt every feat.
They gather wind, by firking up their breeches.
I'll none of these, absurdities in my house.
But words and action married so together,
That shall strike harmony in the ears and eyes
Of the severest, if judicious critics.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Go, be ready:
But you sir are incorrigible, and
Take licence to yourself, to add unto
Your parts, your own free fancy; and sometimes
To alter, or diminish what the writer
With care and skill composed: and when you are
To speak to your coactors in the scene,
You hold interlocutions with the audients.

sp.speaker: Bip.
sp.l: That is a way my lord has been allowed
On elder stages to move mirth and laughter.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes in the days of Tarlton and Kempe,
Before the stage was purged from barbarism,
And brought to the perfection it now shines with.
Then fools and jesters spent their wits, because
The poets were wise enough to save their own
For profitabler uses. Let that pass.
Tonight, I'll give thee leave to try thy wit,
In answering my doctor, and his patient
He brings along with him to our antipodes.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I heard of him my lord: blaze gave me light
Of the mad patient; and that he never saw
A play in's life: it will be possible
For him to think he is in the antipodes
Indeed, when he is on the stage among us.
When't has been thought by some that have their wits,
that all the players i' th' town were sunk passed rising.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Leave that sir to th'event. See all be ready:
Your music properties, and —

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: All my lord,
Only we want a person for a mute.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Blaze when he comes shall serve. Go in. Ex. Byp.
My guests i hear are coming.

div.head: Act 2. Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter blaze, joyless, Diana, Martha Barb.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: My lord, i am become your honour's usher,
To these your guests. The worthy Mr. joyless,
With his fair wife, and daughter in law.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: They're welcome,
And you in the first place sweet mistress joyless.
You wear my ring i see; you grace me in it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: His ring! what ring? how came she by't?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I sent it as a pledge of my affection to you:
For i before have seen you, and do languish,
Until i shall enjoy your love.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Next lady — you — i have a toy for you too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My child shall thank you for it, when I have one.
I take no joy in toys since I was married.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Prettily answered! I make you no stranger
Kind mistress blaze.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Time was your honour used
Me strangely too, as you'll do these I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Honest blaze,
Prithee go in, there is an actor wanting.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Is there a part for me? how shall I study't?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Then if I do not act
Nothing as well as the best of 'em, let me be hissed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I say restore the ring, and back with me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: To whom shall I restore it?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: To the lord that sent it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Is he a lord? I always thought and heard
Ith' country, lords were gallant creatures. He
Looks like a thing not worth it: 'tis not his,
the doctor gave it me, and I will keep it.

sp.speaker: Let
sp.l: I use small verbal courtesy Mr. joyless
(You see) but what I can in deed I'll do.
You know the purpose of your coming, and
I can but give you welcome. If your son
Shall receive ease in't, be the comfort yours,
The credit of't my doctors. You are sad.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: My lord I would entreat we may return;
I fear my wife's not well.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Return I pray slight not so my courtesy.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Besides sir I am well; and have a mind
(A thankful one) to taste my lords free bounty.
I never saw a play, and would be loath
To lose my longing now.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: The air of London
Hath tainted her obedience already:
And should the play but touch the vices of it,
She'd learn and practise 'em. Let me beseech
Your lord ships reacceptance of the un -
Merited favour that she wears here, and
Your leave for our departure.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I will not
Be so dishonoured; nor become so ill
A master of my house, to let a lady
Leave it against her will; and from her longing;
I will be plain wi'ye therefore: if your haste
Must needs post you away, you may depart,
She shall not not till the morning for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Indeed 'tis a high point of honour in
A lord to keep a private gentleman's wife
From him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I love this plain lord better than
All the brave gallant ones, that ere I dreamt on.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: 'Tis time we take our seats. So if you'll stay.
Come sit with us, if not, you know your way.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Here are we fallen through the doctor's fingers.
Into the lords hands. Fate deliver us. Ex. omnes.

div.head: Act. 2. Seen 4.
div.stage: Enter in sea-gownes and caps, doctor, and Perigrine brought in a chair by 2 sailors: cloaks and hats brought in.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Now the last minute of his sleeping fit
Determines. Raise him on his feet. So, so:
Rest him upon mine arm. Remove that chair,
Welcome ashore sir in th' antipodes.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And on firm land.
Sailors you may return now to your ship. Ex. Sail.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What worlds of lands and seas have I passed over,
Neglecting to set down my observations,
A thousand thousand things remarkable
Have slipped my memory, as if all had been
Mere shadowy phantasms, or fantastic dreams.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: We'll write as we return sir: and 'tis true ▪
You slept most part of th' journey hitherward,
The air was so somniferous: and 'twas well
You scaped the calenture by't.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But how long do you think I slept?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Eight months, and some odd days,
Which was but as so many hours and minutes
Of ones own natural country sleep.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Eight months —

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: 'Twas nothing for so young a brain.
How think you one of the seven Christian champions,
David by name, slept seven years in a leek-bed.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I think I have read it in their famous history.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: But what chief thing of note now in our travels
Can you call presently to mind? Speak like a traveller.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do remember, as we passed the verge
O'th' upper world, coming down, downhill,
The setting sun then bidding them good night,
Came gliding easily down by us; and struck
New day before us, lighting us our way;
But with such heat, that till he was got far
Before us, we even melted.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Well wrought potion. Very well observed sir.
But now we are come into a temperate clime
of equal composition of elements
With that of London; and as well agreeable
Unto our nature, as you have found that air.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Cry you mercy.
This sir is anti London. That's the antipodes
To the grand city of our nation,
Just the same people, language, and religion,
But contrary in manners, as I ha' told you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do remember that relation,
As if you had but given it me this morning.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Now cast your sea weeds off, and don fresh garments.
Hark sir their music.

div.head: Act 2. Scene 5.
div.stage: Shift. Hoboys. Enter Letoy, joyless, Diana, Martha, barara, in masques, they sit at the other end of the stage.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Here we may sit, and he not see us.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Now see one of the natives of this country,
Note his attire, his language, and behaviour.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.l: Our far fetched title over lands and seas,
Offers unto your view th'antipodes.
But what antipodes now shall you see?
Even those that foot to foot 'gainst London be,
Because no traveller that knows that state,
Shall say we personate or imitate
Them in our actions: for nothing can
Almost be spoke, but some or other man,
Takes it unto himself; and says the stuff,
If it be vicious, or absurd enough.
Was woven upon his back. Far, far be all
That bring such prejudice mixed with their gall.
This play shall no satiric Timist be
To tax or touch at either him or thee,
That art notorious. 'tis so far below
Things in our orb, that do among us flow,
That no degree, from keyser to the clown,
Shall say this vice or folly was mine own.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: This had been well now, if you had not dreamt
Too long upon your syllables. Ex. prol.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The prologue call you this my lord?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis my lord's reader, and as good a lad
Out of his function, as I would desire
To mix withal in civil conversation.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes lady, this was prologue to the play,
As this is to our sweet ensuing pleasures. Kiss.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Kissing indeed is prologue to a play,
Composed by th'devil, and acted by the children
Of his black revels, may hell take ye for't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed I am weary, and would fain go home.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Indeed but you must stay; and see the play.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The play: what play? It is no children's play,
Nor no child-getting play, pray is it?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You'll see anon. O now the actors enter. Flourish.

div.head: Act 2. Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter two sergeants, with swords drawn, running before a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why do you not your office courteous friends?
Let me entreat you stay, and take me with you;
Lay but your hands on me: I shall not rest
Until I be arrested. A sore shoulder-ache
Pains and torments me, till your virtuous hands
Do clap or stroke it.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: And I beseech you pardon our intent,
Which was indeed to have arrested you:
But sooner shall the charter of the city
Be forfeited, than varlets (Like ourselves)
Shall wrong a gentleman's peace. So fare you well sir. Ex.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Two catchpoles
Run from a gentleman (It seems) that would
Have been arrested.

div.head: Act 2. Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter old lady and by play, like a servingman.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Yonder's your master,
Go take him you in hand, while I fetch breath,

sp.speaker: Bip.
sp.l: O are you here? my lady, and myself
Have sought you sweetly.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: You, and your lady, you
Should ha' said puppy.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: For we heard you were
To be arrested. Pray sir, who has bailed you?
I wonder who of all your bold acquaintance
That knows my lady durst bail off her husband.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Have you not made
An end by composition, and disbursed
Some of my lady's money for a peace
That shall beget an open war upon you?
Confess it if you have: for 'twill come out.
She'll ha' you up you know. I speak it for your good.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I know't, and I'll entreat my lady wife
To mend thy wages tother forty shillings
A year, for thy true care of me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: 'Tis well sir,
But now (If thou hast impudence so much,
As face to face, to speak unto a lady
That is thy wife, and supreme head) tell me
At whose suit was it? or upon what action?
Debts I presume you have none: for who dares trust
A lady's husband, who is but a squire,
And under covert barn? it is some trespass —
Answer me not till I find out the truth.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The truth is —

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Peace,
How dar'st thou speak the truth
Before thy wife? I'll find it out myself.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: In truth she handles him handsomely.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Yes, and such wives are worthy to be liked,
For giving good example.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Good! hold up
That humour by all means.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I think I ha' found it.
There was a certain mercer sent you silks,
And cloth of gold to get his wife with child;
You slighted her, and answered not his hopes;
And now he lays to arrest you; is't not so?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: For shame
Be not ingrateful to that honest man,
To take his wares, and scorn to lie with his wife.
Do't I command you; what did I marry you for?
The portion that you brought me was not so
Abundant, though it were five thousand pounds
(Considering too the jointure that I made you)
That you should disobey me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: It seems the husbands
In the antipodes bring portions, and
The wives make jointures.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And wives, when they are old, and passed childbearing,
Allow their youthful husbands other women.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Right. And old men give their young wives like licence.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That I like well. Why should not our old men,
Love their young wives as well?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Peace master joyless, you are too loud. Good still,

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Do as my lady bids, you got her woman
With child at half these words.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O, but another's
Wife is another thing. Far be it from
A gentleman's thought to do so, having a wife
And handmaid of his own that he likes better.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: There said you well; but take heed I advise you
How you love your own wench, or your own wife
Better than other men's.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Go to that woman, if she prove with child,
I'll take it as mine own.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Her husband would
Do so. But from my house I may not stray.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If it be me your wife commends you to,
You shall not need to stray from your own house.
I'll go home with you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Precious! what do you mean?
Pray keep your seat: you'll put the players out.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Here's goodly stuff! She's in the antipodes too.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: All Antipodeans ▪
Attend good sir.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You know your charge, obey it.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: What is his charge? or whom must he obey?
Good madam with your wild authority;
You are his wife, 'tis true, and therein may
According to our law, rule, and control him.
But you must know withal, I am your servant,
And bound by the same law to govern you,
And be a stay to you in declining age,
To curb and qualify your headstrong will,
Which otherwise would ruin you. Moreover,
Though you're his wife, I am a breeding mother,
Of a dear child of his; and therein claim
More honour from him than you ought to challenge.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: You have something there to look to, one would think,
If you had any care. How well you saw
Your father at school today, and knowing how apt
He is to play the truant.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But is he not
Yet gone to school?

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.p: Stand by, and you shall see.

div.head: Act. 2. Scene. 9.
div.stage: Enter three old men with sachells, etc.

sp.speaker: All. 3.
sp.p: Dominae, dominae duster. Three knaves in a cluster, etc.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O this is gallant pastime nay come on,
Is this your school? was that your lesson, ha?

sp.speaker: 1 old
sp.p: Pray now good son, indeed, indeed.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Indeed
You shall to school, away with him; and take
Their wagships with him; the whole cluster of 'em.

sp.speaker: 2 old
sp.p: You shan't send us now, so you shan't.

sp.speaker: 3 old
sp.p: We be none of your father, so we beant.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Away with 'em I say; and tell their schoolmistress,
What truants they are, and bid her pay 'em soundly.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Alas, will nobody beg pardon for
The poor old boys?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Sir, gentle sir, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: To stranger's sir I can be gentle.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Good,
Now mark that fellow, he speaks extempore.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Extempore call you him? he's a dogged fellow
To the three poor old things there, fie upon him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Do men of such fair years here go to school?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Have you no young men scholars, sir I pray;
When we have beard less doctors?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: He has wiped my lips, you question very wisely sir.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: So sir have we; and many reverend teachers,
Grave counsellors at law; perfect statesmen.
That never knew use of razor, which may live
For want of wit to lose their offices.
These were great scholars in their youth. But when
Age grows upon men here, their learning wastes,
And so decays; that if they live until
Threescore, their sons send them to school again.
They'd die as speechless else as new born children.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis a wise nation; and the piety
Of the young men most rare and commendable,
Yet give me as a stranger leave to beg
Their liberty this day; and what they lose by't,
My father when he goes to school, shall answer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I am abused on that side too.

sp.speaker: Bypt.
sp.l: 'Tis granted.
Hold up your heads and thank the gentleman
Like scholars, with your heels now.

sp.speaker: All. 3.
sp.l: Gratias, gratias, gratias. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Well done son Peregrine, he's in's wits I hope.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: If you lose yours the while, where's my advantage?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And trust me, 'twas well done too of extempore
To let the poor old children lose. And now
I look well on him he's a proper man.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: She'll fall in love with the actor, and undo me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Does not his lady love him, sweet my lord?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Love; yes, and lie with him, as her husband does
With's maid. It is their law in the antipodes.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: But we have no such laws with us.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Do you approve of such a law?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: No; not so much
In this case, where the man and wife do lie
With their inferior servants; but in the other,
Where the old citizen would arrest the gallant
That took his wares and would not lie with's wife,
There it seems reasonable, very reasonable.

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.l: Make't your own case, you are an old man,
I love a gentleman, you give him rich presents,
To get me a child (Because you cannot) must not
We look to have our bargain?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Give me leave
Now to be gone my lord, though I leave her
Behind me; she is mad, and not my wife,
And I may leave her.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Come; you are moved I see,
I'll settle all; but first, prevail with you
To taste my wine and sweet meats. The comedians
Shall pause the while. This you must not deny me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I must not live here always, that's my comfort. Exit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I thank you sir, for the poor men's release,
It was the first request that I have made
Since I came in these confines.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: 'Tis our custom
To deny strangers nothing: yea, to offer
Of any thing we have, that may be useful,
In courtesy to strangers. Will you therefore
Be pleased to enter sir this habitation,
And take such viands, beverage, and repose
As may refresh you after tedious travails?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Thou takest him right: for I am sure he's hungry.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: All I have seen since my arrival, are
Wonders. But your humanity excels.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: Virtue in the antipodes only dwells.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yet, Mr. joyless, are you pleased? you see
Here's nothing but fair play, and all above board.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: But it is late, and these long intermissions
By banqueting and courtship twixt the acts
Will keep back the catastrophe of your play,
Until the morning light.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: And then in midst of scenes
You interrupt your actors; and tie them
To lengthen time in silence, while you hold
Discourse, by th'by.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Pox o'thy jealousy.
Because I give thy wife a look, or word
Sometimes! What if I kiss (Thus) I'll not eat her.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: So, so, his banquet works with him.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And for my actors, they shall speak, or not speak
As much, or more, or less, and when I please,
It is my way of pleasure, and I'll use it.
So sit: they enter. Flourish.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Your case is clear, I understand it fully,
And need no more instructions, this shall serve,
To firk your adversary from court to court,
If he stand out upon rebellious legs,
But till Octabis Michaelis next.
I'll bring him on submissive knees.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: A lawyer, and his client there, a poet.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Goes law so torn, and poetry so brave?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Will you but give the actors leave to speak,
They may have done the sooner?

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Let me see,
This is your bill of parcels.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Yes, of all
My several wares, according to the rates
Delivered unto my debtor,

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes, poetry is good ware
In the antipodes, though there be some ill payers,
As well as here; but law there rights the poets.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Delivered too, and for the use of the right worshipful
Mr. alderman humble-bee, as followeth — imprimis —Reads.
Umh, I cannot read your hand; your character
Is bad, and your orthography much worse.
Read it yourself pray.

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.l: Do aldermen
Love poetry in Antipodea London.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Better than ours do custards; but the worst
Paymasters living there; worse than our gallants,
Partly for want of money, partly wit.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Can aldermen want wit and money too?
That's wonderful.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Imprimis sir here is
For three religious madrigals to be sung
By th' holy vestals in Bridewell, for the
Conversion of our city wives and daughters,
Ten groats a piece, it was his own agreement.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Item, twelve hymns,
For the twelve sessions, during his shrievalty,
Sung by the choir of Newgate, in the praise
Of city clemency (For in that year
No guiltless person suffered by their judgement)
Ten groats a piece also.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Why speaks your poet so demurely?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: O —
'Tis a precise tone he has got among
The sober sisterhood.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: O I remember,
The doctor said poets were all Puritans
In the antipodes: but where's the doctor?
And where's your son my joyless?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Item,
A distich graven in his thumb-ring,
Of all the wise speeches and sayings of all
His alder predecessors, and his brothers
In two Kings reigns.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Two pieces he promised to me for it.
Item, inscriptions in his hall and parlour,
His gallery, and garden, round the walls,
Of his own public acts, between the time
He was a common council man and sheriff,
One thousand lines put into wholesome verse.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.p: Here's a sum towards indeed ▪ a thousand verses?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: They come too, at the known rate of the city.
(That is to say at forty pence the score)
Eight pounds six shillings, eight pence.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Item, an elegy for mistress alderwoman
Upon the death of one of her coach-mares,
She prized above her daughter, being crooked —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis true, for I should weep for that poor daughter,
'Tis like she'll have no children, pray now look,
Am not I crooked too?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Item, a love epistle for the aldermanikin his son,
And a book of the godly life and death
Of mistress Katherine stubs, which I have turned
Into sweet metre, for the virtuous youth,
To woe an ancient lady widow with.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Here's a large sum in all, for which I'll try,
His strength in law, till he peccavi cry,
when I shall sing, for all his present bigness,
Jamque opus exegi quod nec jovis ira, nec ignis ▪

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The lawyer speaks the poet's part.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: He thinks
The more; the poets in th' antipodes,
Are slow of tongue, but nimble with the pen.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: The counsel and the comfort you have given
Me, requires a double fee. Offers money.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Will you abuse me therefore?
I take no fees double nor single I.
Retain your money, you retain not me else.
Away, away, you'll hinder other clients.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to send then to your wife.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Not so much as a poesy for her thimble,
For fear I spoil your cause,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: What a poor honest lawyer's this?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: They are all so
In th' antipodes.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: You're welcome captain.
In your two causes I have done my best.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And what's the issue pray sir?

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Truly sir,
Our best course is not to proceed to trial.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Your reason? I shall then recover nothing.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Yes, more by composition, than the court
Can lawfully adjudge you, as I have laboured.
And sir, my course is, where I can compound
A difference, I'll not toss nor bandy it
Into the hazard of a judgement.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Still
An honest lawyer, and though poor, no marvel ▪

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: First you understand
Your several actions, and your adversaries ▪
The first a battery against a coachman,
That beat you sorely ▪

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What hard hearted fellow
Could beat so spruce a gentleman, and a captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: By this fair hilt, he did sir, and so bruised
My arms, so crushed my ribs, and stitched my sides,
That I have had no heart to draw my sword since;
And shall I put it up, and not his purse
Be made to pay for't?

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: It is up already, sir,
If you can be advised, observe I pray,
Your other actions 'gainst your feathermaker,
And that of trespass for th'incessant trouble
He puts you to by importunate requests,
To pay him no money, but take longer day.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Against all humane reason, for although
I have bought feathers of him these four years,
And never paid him a penny; yet he duns me
So desperately to keep my money still,
As if I ought him nothing; he haunts and breaks my sleeps.
I swear sir, by the motion of this I wear now,Shakes it.
I have had twenty better feathers of him, and as ill paid for ▪
Yet still he duns me to forbear my payment,
And to take longer day.
I ha' not said my prayers in
Mine own lodging sir this twelvemonths day,
For sight or thought of him; and how can you
Compound this action, or the other of
That Russian coachman that durst lift a hand
'Gainst a commander.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Very easily thus,
The coachman's poor, and scarce his twelvemonth's wages
Though't be five marks a year will satisfy.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Pray name no sum in marks, I have had too many
Of's marks already.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: So you owe the other
A debt of twenty pound, the coachman now
Shall for your satisfaction, beat you out
Of debt.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: No sir he shall beat
for you your feather man till he take his money.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: So I'll be satisfied, and help him to
More customers of my rank.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Leave it to me then,
It shall be by posterity repeaten
That soldiers ought not to be dund or beaten,
Away and keep your money.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: An honest lawyer, still how he considers
The weak estate of a young gentleman
At arms — but who comes here? A woman.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes; that has taken up the newest fashion
Of the town-militasters.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Is it buff,
Or calf skin trow? she looks as she could beat
Out a whole tavern garrison before her
Of mill tasters call you 'em? if her husband
Be an old jealous man now, and can please herLawyer reads on papers.
No better than most ancient husbands can,
I warrant she makes herself good upon him.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: 'Tis very good, the play begins to please me.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: I wait to speak wi'ye sir, but must I stand
Your construing and piercing of your scribblings.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Thus far I have proceeded in your cause
Ith' marshals court.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: But shall I have the combat?

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: Pray observe
The passages of my proceedings; and
The pro's and contras in the windings, workings
And carriage of the cause.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Fah on your passages,
Your windy workings, and your fizzlings at
The bar. Come me toth' point, is it decreed,
A combat?

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.p: Well, it is; and here's your order.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Now thou hast spoken like a lawyer,
And here's thy fee.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Take it, or I will beat thy carcase thinner
Than thou hast worn thy gown here.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.p: Must I then take you in hand?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Alas poor man, he will take money yet,
Rather than blows, and so far he agrees
With our rich lawyers, that sometimes give blows
And shrewd ones for their money.

sp.speaker: Buff.
sp.l: Now victory
Afford me fate, or bravely let me die. Exit.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: You shall see that anon —

div.head: Act. 3. Scene. 5.
div.stage: Enter a beggar, and a gallant.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: What's here, what's here?
A courtier, or some gallant practising
The beggar's trade, who teaches him I think.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Sir excuse me, I have
From time to time supplied you without hope,
Or purpose to receive least retribution
From you, no not so much as thanks or bare
Acknowledgement of the free benefits,
I have conferred upon you.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Yet do you now when that my present store
Responds not my occasions ▪ seek to oppress me
With vain petitionary breath, for what I may not
Give without fear of dangerous detriment?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: In what a phrase the ragged orator
Displays himself.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: The beggars are the
Most absolute courtiers in th' antipodes.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: If not a piece, yet spare me half a piece
For goodness' sake good sir, did you but know
My instant want, and to what virtuous use,
I would distribute it, I know you would not
hold back your charity.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And how feelingly
He begs; then as the beggars are the best
Courtiers, it seems the courtiers are best beggars
In the antipodes; how contrary in all
Are they to us?

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Pray to what virtuous uses
Would you put money to now, if you had it?

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: I would bestow a crown in ballads,
Love-pamphlets, and such poetical rarities,
To send down to my lady grandmother.
She's very old you know, and given much
To contemplation; I know she'll send me for 'em,
In puddings, bacon, souse and pot-butter
Enough to keep my chamber all this winter.
So shall I save my father's whole allowance
To lay upon my back, and not be forced
To shift out from my study for my victuals.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: I would bestow another crown in
Hobby-horses, and rattles for my grandfather,
Whose legs and hearing fail him very much ▪
Then to preserve his sight a jack-a-lent,
In a green sarsenet suit, he'll make my father
To send me one of scarlet, or he'll cry
His eyes out for't.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: I have but just a fee left for my lawyer;
If he exact not that, I'll give it thee.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He'll take no fee (That's sure enough young man)
Of beggars, I know that.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I'll speak to him myself else to remit it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: You will not sure, will you turn actor too?
Pray do, be put in for a share amongst 'em?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: How must I be put in?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: The players will quickly
Show you, if you perform your part; perhaps
they may want one to act the whore amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Fie master joyless, you're too foul.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: My lord,
She is too fair it seems in your opinion,
For me, therefore if you can find it lawful,
Keep her; I will be gone.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Now I protest
Sit and sit civilly, till the play be done,
I'll lock thee up else, as I am true Letoy.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Nay I ha' done —Whistles Fortune my foe.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.p: Give me my fee, I cannot hear you else.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Sir I am poor, and all I get, is at
The hands of charitable givers; pray sir.

sp.speaker: Lawyer
sp.l: You understand me sir, your cause is to be
Pleaded today, or you are quite o'erthrown in't.
The judge by this time is about to sit.
Keep fast your money, and forgo your wit. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Then I must follow, and entreat him to it,
Poor men in law must not disdain to do it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gallant
sp.l: Do it then, I'll follow you and hear the cause. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: True Antipodians still, for as with us,
The gallants follow lawyers, and the beggars them;
The lawyer here is followed by the beggar,
While the gentleman follows him.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: The moral is, the lawyers here prove beggars,
And beggars only thrive by going to law.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: How takes the lawyers then the beggar's money?
And none else by their wills?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: They send it all
Up to our lawyers, to stop their mouths,
That curse poor clients that are put upon 'em.
In forma pauperis.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: In truth most charitable,
But sure that money's lost by'th way sometimes.
Yet sweet my lord, whom do these beggars beg of,
That they can get aforehand so for law?
Who are their benefactors?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Then they have usurers in th' antipodes too?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes usury goes round the world, and will do,
Till the general conversion of the Jews.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But ours are not so charitable I fear.
Who be their usurers?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Soldiers, and courtiers chiefly;
And some that pass for grave and pious churchmen.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: How finely contrary they're still to ours.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Why do you not enter, what are you asleep? —

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: My lord the mad young gentleman. —

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: He has got into our tiring-house amongst us,
And ta'en a strict survey of all our properties,
Our statues and our images of gods; our planets and our constellations
Our giants, monsters, furies, beasts, and bugbears,
Our helmets shields, and vizors, hairs, and beards,
Our pasteboard marchpanes, and our wooden pies.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Sirrah be brief, be not you now as long in
Telling what he saw, as he surveying.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Whether he thought was some enchanted castle,
Or temple, hung and piled with monuments
Of uncouth, and of various aspects,
I dive not to his thoughts, wonder he did
A while it seemed, but yet undaunted stood:
When on the sudden, with thrice knightly force,
And thrice, thrice, puissant arm he snatcheth down
The sword and shield that I played R●vis with,
Rusheth amongst the foresaid properties,
Kills monster, after monster; takes the puppets
Prisoners, knocks down the Cyclops, tumbles all
Our jigambobs and trinkets to the wall.
Spying at last the crown and royal robes
Ith' upper wardrobe, next to which by chance,
The devil's vizors hung, and their flame painted
Skin coats; those he removed with greater fury,
And (Having cut the infernal ugly faces,
All into mammocks) with a reverend hand,
He takes the imperial diadem and crowns
Himself King of the antipodes, and believes
he has justly gained the kingdom by his conquest.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Doctor Hughball
Hath soothed him in't, so that nothing can
Be said against it, he begins to govern
With purpose to reduce the manners
Of this country to his own, h'has constituted
The doctor his chief officer; whose secretary
I am to be, you'll see a court well ordered.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I see th'event already, by the aimLetoy whispers with Barbara.
The doctor takes, proceed you with your play,
And let him see it in what state he pleases.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Trust me, this same extempore,
(I know not's tother name) pleases me better
For absolute action then all the rest.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: You were best beg him of his lord.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Say you so?
He's busy, or I'd move him,

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Prithee do so,
Good mistress blaze; go with her gentle lady ▪To marth.
Do as she bids you, you shall get a child by't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'll do as anybody bids me for a child.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Diana yet be wise, bear not the name
Of sober chastity to play the beast in.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Think not yourself, nor make yourself a beast,
Before you are one, and when you appear so,
Then thank yourself; your jealousy durst not trust me,
Behind you in the country, and since I'm here,
I'll see and know, and follow th'fashion; if
It be to cuckold you, I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I now could wish my son had been as far
In the antipodes as he thinks himself,
Ere I had run this hazard.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And I'll perform't I warrant you my lord. Ex. Ba. Mar.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Why should you wish so? had you rather lose
Your son then please your wife? you show your love both ways.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing. —

div.head: Act. 3. Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter Byplay the governor, mace-bearer, swordbearer, officer, the mace and sword laid on the table, the governor sits.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: No 'tis the city governor,
And the chief judge within their corporation.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Here's a cityEnter Peregine and doctor.
Like to be well governed then. —

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Yonder's a King, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: 'Tis your son,
My joyless, now you're pleased.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Would you were pleased,
To cease your housewifry in spinning out
The play at length thus.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Here sir, you shall see
A point of justice handled.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: Call the defendant, and the plaintiff in.

sp.speaker: Byp:
sp.l: How now!
How long ha' you been free oath pointmakers,
Good master hilt and scabbard carrier;
(Which is in my hands now) do you give order
For counsel and for witnesses in a cause
Fit for my hearing, or for me to judge, haw?
I must be ruled and circumscribed by lawyers must I,
And witnesses haw? no you shall know
I can give judgement, be it right or wrong,
Without their needless proving and defending:
So bid the lawyers go and shake their ears,
If they have any, and the witnesses,
Preserve their breath to prophesy of dry summers.
Bring me the plaintiff, and defendant only:
But the defendant first, I will not hear
Any complaint before I understand
What the defendant can say for himself.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I have not known such down right equity,
If he proceeds as he begins, I'll grace him. —

sp.speaker: By.
sp.p: Now sir, are you the plaintiff or defendant, haw?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Both as the case requires my lord.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I cannot
Hear two at once, speak first as you're defendant.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I will hear no
Complaint, I say speak your defence.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: For silks and
Stuffs received by me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Yes my good lord, he doth not now complain.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: For money nor for wares
Again: but he complains.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.p: Complains again? do you double with me, haw?

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Of his wife, does he, haw? That I must confess
Is many a good man's case; you may proceed.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: In money I tender him double satisfaction,
With his own wares again unblemished, undishonoured.

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.l: What an odd
Jeering judge is this?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But unto me,
They were delivered upon this condition,
That I should satisfy his wife.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: He'll have
Your body for her then, unless I empt
My breast of mercy to appease her for you,
