Call in the plaintiff; sir, stand you aside. Exit officer.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: O 'tis the flinching gentleman that broke
With the kind citizen's wife. I hope the judge
Will make him an example.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Come you forwards,
Yet nearer man, i know my face is terrible,
and that a citizen had rather lose
His debt, then that a judge should truly know
His dealings with a gentleman, yet speak,
Repeat without thy shop book now; and without
Fear, it may rise in judgement here against thee.
What is thy full demand? what satisfaction
Requirest thou of this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: And please you sir —

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: 'Twas well said sword-bearer,
Thou knowest thy place, which is to show correction.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: My lord an't please you, if it like your honour.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: La! an intelligent citizen, and may grow
In time himself to sit in place of worship.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: I ask no satisfaction of the gentleman,
But to content my wife; what her demand is,
'Tis best known to herself; please her, please me,
An't please you sir — my lord an't like your honour.
But before he has given her satisfaction,
I may not fall my suit, nor draw my action.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: No alack a day I may not,
Nor find content, nor peace at home, an't please you
(My lord, an't like your honour I would say)
An't please you, what's a tradesman, that
Has a fair wife, without his wife, an't please you?
And she without content is no wife, considering
We tradesmen live by gentlemen, an't please you,
And our wives drive a half trade with us, if the gentlemen
Break with our wives, our wives are no wives to us,
And we but broken tradesmen, an't please you.
An't like your honour, my good lord, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Yet gentlemen,
A lack a day, and please you, and like your honour,
Will not consider our necessities,
And our desire in general through the city,
To have our sons all gentlemen like them.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Nor though a gentleman consume
His whole estate among ye, yet his son
may live t'inherit it?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Right, right, an't please you:
Your honour my good lord an't please you.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Well,
This has so little to be said against it,
That you say nothing. Gentlemen it seems
You're obstinate, and will stand out —

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My lord,
Rather than not to stand out with all men's wives,
Except mine own, I'll yield me into prison.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: If our young gentlemen,
Were like those of th'antipodes, what decay
Of trade would here be, and how full the prisons?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I offer him any other satisfaction;
His wares again, or money twice the value.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Ay, ay, alack a day,
Nor do I sue to have him up in prison,
Alack a day, what good (Good gentleman)
Can I get by his body?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Peace, I should
Now give my sentence, and for your contempt,
(Which is a great one, such as if let pass
Unpunished, may spread forth a dangerous
Example ▪ to the breach of city custom,
By gentlemen's neglect of tradesmen's wives)
I should say for this contempt commit you
Prisoner from sight of any other woman,
Until you give this man's wife satisfaction,
And she release you; justice so would have it:
But as I am a citizen by nature,
(For education made it so) I'll use
Urbanity in your behalf towards you;
And as I am a gentleman by calling,
(For so my place must have it) I'll perform
For you the office of a gentleman
Towards his wife, I therefore order thus;
That you bring me the wares here into court,
(I have a chest shall hold 'em, as mine own)
And you send me your wife, I'll satisfy her
Myself. I'll do't, and set all straight and right:
Justice is blind, but judges have their sight.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And feeling too in the antipodes ▪
Han't they my lord?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: What's that to you my lady?
Within.dismiss the court.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Dismiss the court, cannot you hear the prompter?
Have you lost your ears, judge?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: No: dismiss the court,
Embrace you friends, and to shun further strife,
See you send me your stuff, and you your wife.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Protest extempore played the judge; and I
Knew him not all this while.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: What oversight
Was there?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He is a properer man methinks
Now, than he was before: sure I shall love him.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Sure, sure, you shall not, shall you?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And I warrant,
By his judgement speech e'en now, he loves a woman well:
For he said, if you noted him, that he
Would satisfy the citizen's wife himself.
Methinks a gentlewoman might please him better.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: How dare you talk so? Byplay kneels, and kisses Peregrine's hand.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: What's he a doing now trow?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Kneel down
Again. Give me a sword somebody .

sp.speaker: Let
sp.p: The king's about to knight him.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Let me pray
Your majesty be pleased, yet to withhold
That undeserved honour, till you first
Vouchsafe to grace the city with your presence,
Accept one of our hall-feasts, and a freedom,
And freely use our purse for what great sums
Your majesty will please.

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.l: What subjects there are
In the antipodes.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: None in the world so loving.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Give me a sword, I say, must I call thrice?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: No, no, take mine my liege.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: A loyal lord, one of your subjects too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He may be loyal; he's a wondrous plain one,

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Prithee Diana, yet let's slip away
Now while he's busy.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: But where's your daughter in law?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Gone home I warrant you with mistress blaze.
Let them be our example.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You're an impudent whore,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I know not what I may be
Made by your jealousy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'll none of this,
Give me that princely weapon.

sp.speaker: Sword bearer
sp.l: It is a property you know my lord,
No blade, but a rich scabbard with a lath in't.

sp.speaker: Let
sp.p: So is the sword of justice for ought he knows.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Yet on me let it fall,
Since 'tis your highness' will, scabbard and all.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Rise up our trusty well beloved knight.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Let me find favour in your gracious sight
To taste a banquet now, which is prepared,
And shall be by your followers quickly shared.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Come sirs quickly. Ent. 5. or 6. Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And must not we
Go to the banquet too?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: He must not see
You yet; I have provided otherwise
For both you in my chamber, and from thence
We'll at a window see the rest oth' play,
Or if you needs sir will stay here, you may.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: Was ever man betrayed thus into torment? Ex.

div.head: Act 4. Scene. 1.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Now sir be pleased to cloud your princely raiment
With this disguise. Great Kings have done the like,
To make discovery of passagesPuts on a cloak and hat.
Among the people: thus you shall perceive
What to approve, and what correct among 'em.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And so I'll cherish, or severely punish.

div.stage: Enter an old woman reading: to her, a young maid.

sp.speaker: Old_merrithought
sp.p: Royal pastime, in a great match between the tanners and the butchers, six dogs of aside , to play single at the game bear, for fifty pound, and a ten pound supper, for their dogs and themselves. Also you shall see two ten dog-courses at the great bear.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Fie granny fie, can no persuasions,
Threatenings, nor blows prevail, but you'll persist
In these profane and diabolical courses,
To follow bear baitings, when you can scarce
Spell out their bills with spectacles?

sp.speaker: Old_merrithought
sp.l: What though
My sight be gone beyond the reach of spectacles,
In any print but this, and though I cannot,
(No, no, I cannot read your meditations)Strikes down her book.
Yet I can see the royal game played over and over,
And tell which dog does best, without my spectacles.
And though I could not, yet I love the noise;
The noise revives me, and the bear-garden scent
Refresheth much my smelling.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Let me entreat you
Forbear such beastly pastimes, they're satanical.

sp.speaker: Old_merrithought
sp.p: Take heed child what you say, 'tis the King's game.

sp.speaker: Old_merrithought
sp.l: A bear's a princely beast, and one side venison
(Writ a good author once) you yet want years,
And are with baubles pleased, I'll see the bears. Exit.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: And I must bear with it. she's full of wine,
And for the present wilful; but in due
Season I'll humble her: but we are all
Too subject to infirmity.

div.head: Act 4. Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter a young gentleman, and an old servingman.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yes sir, old servants are
But boys to masters, be they ne'er so young.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Take mine, and keep you warm then,
I'll wear yours.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Out you varlet,
Dost thou obscure it, as thou meantst to pawn it?
Is this a cloak unworthy of the light?
Publish it sirrah: — o presumptuous slave,
Display it on one arm — o ignorance!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Pray load your ass yourself, as you would have it ▪

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nay prithee be not angry: thus, and now
Be sure you bear't at no such distance; but
As't may be known appendix to this book.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This custom I have seen with us.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yes, but
It was derived from the antipodes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: It is a dainty creature, and my blood
Rebels against the spirit: I must speak to him.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir here's a gentlewoman makes towards you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Me? she's deceived, I am not for her mowing.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Fair sir, may you vouchsafe my company?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: No truly, I am none of those you look for.
The way is broad enough, unhand me pray you.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Pray sir be kinder to a lass that loves you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Some such there are, but I am none of those.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Come, this is but a copy of your countenance.
I ha' known you better than you think I do.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: What ha' you known me for?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I knew you once
For half a piece I take it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are deceived
The whole breadth of your nose, I scorn it.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Come be not coy, but send away your servant,
And let me give you a pint of wine.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pray keep
Your courtesy, I can bestow the wine
Upon myself, if I were so disposed,
To drink in taverns; fah.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Let me bestow't
Upon you at your lodging then; and there
Be civilly merry.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Which if you do,
My wife shall thank you for it; but your better
Course is to seek one fitter for your turn,
You'll lose your aim in me; and I befriend you
To tell you so.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Gip gaffer shotten, fagh,
Take that for your coy counsel. Kicks.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Peace good master,
And come away. Some cowardly jade I warrant,
That durst not strike a woman.

div.head: Act 4. Scene 3.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: But and we were your match. —

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: What would you do?
Come, come afore the constable: now if
You were her match, what would you do sir?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Do?
They have done too much already sir: a virginWeeps.
Shall not pass shortly for these street-walkers,
if some judicious order be not taken.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Sir, speak to your companions,
I have a wife and daughters, and am bound,
By hourly precepts, to hear women first,
Be't truth, or no truth, therefore virgin speak,
And fear no bug bears, I will do thee justice.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Sir, they assailed me, and with violent hands,
When words could not prevail, they would have drawn me
Aside unto their lust till I cried murder.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Protest sir, as I am a gentleman,
And as my man's a man she beat us both,
Till I cried murder.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: You are a party, and no witness sir,
Besides you're two, and one is easier
To be believed: moreover as you have the odds
In number, what were justice, if it should not support
The weaker side? Away with them to the counter.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Here's much to be reformed, young man thy virtue
Hath won my favour, go, thou art at large.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He puts me out, my part is now
To bribe the constable.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: No matter go —Exit. Gent. and servant.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And you sir, take that sober seeming wanton,
And clap her up, till I hear better of her,
I'll strip you of your office and your ears else.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: They are an ignorant nation,
And have my pity mingled with correction:
And therefore, damsel (For you are the first
Offender I have noted here, and this
Your first offence (For ought I know)

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Go and transgress no more,
and as you find my mercy sweet, see that
You be not cruel to your grandmother,
When she returns from bear-baiting.

div.stage: Enter Buffe woman, her head and face bleeding, and many women, as from a pri●e.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: A woman fencer, that has played a prize,
It seems, with loss of blood.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It doth amaze me. They pass over.
What can her husband be, when she's a fencer?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: He keeps a school, and teacheth needlework,
Or some such arts which we call womanish.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis most miraculous and wonderful.
Man scold within.rogues, varlets, harlots, ha' you done
Your worst, or would you drown me? would you take my life?
Women within.duck him again, duck him again.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Some man it seems, that's ducked for scolding.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: So, so,
Enough, enough, he will be quiet now.

sp.speaker: Mansc.
sp.l: How know you that, you devil ridden witch you?
How, quiet; why quiet? has not the law ▪ past on me,
Over, and over me, and must I be quiet?

sp.speaker: 1 woman
sp.p: Will you incur the law the second time?

sp.speaker: Mansc.
sp.l: The laws the river, is't? yes 'tis a river,
Through which great men, and cunning, wade, or swim;
But mean and ignorant must drown in't; no
You hags and hellhounds, witches, bitches, all,
That were the law, the judge, and executioners,
To my vexation, I hope to see
More flames about your ears, than all the water
You cast me in can quench.

sp.speaker: 3 woman
sp.p: In with him again, he calls us names.

sp.speaker: 2 woman
sp.p: No, no: I charge ye no.

sp.speaker: Mansc.
sp.l: Was ever harmless creature so abused?
To be drenched under water, to learn dumbness
Amongst the fishes, as I were forbidden
To use the natural members I was born with,
And of them all, the chief that man takes pleasure in;
The tongue; o me accursed wretch.Weeps.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is this a man?
I ask not by his beard, but by his tears.

sp.speaker: 1 woman
sp.l: This shower will spend the fury of his tongue,
And so the tempest's over.

sp.speaker: 2 woman
sp.l: I am sorry for't,
I would have had him ducked once more;
But somebody will shortly raise the storm
In him again I hope for us, to make
More holiday-sport of him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sure these are dreams,
Nothing but dreams.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: No, doubtless we are awake sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Can men and women be so contrary
In all that we hold proper to each sex?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I'm glad he takes a taste of sense in that yet.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Twill ask long time and study to reduce
Their manners to our government.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: These are
Low things and easy to be qualified —
But see sir, here come courtiers, note their manners.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: This was three shillings yesterday, how now!
All gone but this? six pence, for leather soles
To my new green silk stockings, and a groat
My ordinary in pompions baked with onions.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: Three pence I lost at nine-pines; but I got
Six tokens towards that at pigeon holes —
Is nails where's the rest; is my poke bottom broke?

sp.speaker: 2 Cour.
sp.p: What Jack! A pox o'ertake thee not; how dost? Kick.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: What with a vengeance ail'st? dost think my breech
Is made of bell mettle? take that. Box o'th ear.

sp.speaker: 2 courtier
sp.l: Pox rot your hold, let go my lock, do think
You're currying of your father's horse again?

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: I'll teach you to abuse a man behind,They buffet.
Was troubled too much afore.

sp.speaker: 3 courtier
sp.l: Hay, there boys, there.
Good boys are good boys still. There will, there Jack.
Not a blow, now he's down.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: There's as proud fall, as stand in court or city.

sp.speaker: 3 courtier
sp.l: That's well said will, troth I commend you both.
How fell you out? I hope in no great anger.

sp.speaker: 2 courtier
sp.p: For mine own part I vow I was in jest.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: But I have told you twice and once, will, jest not
With me behind I never could endure
(Not of a boy) to put up things behind:
And that my tutor knew; I had been a scholar else.
Besides you know my sword was nocked i'th' fashion,
Just here behind, for my back-guard and all;
And yet you would do't.
I had a lief you would take a knife —

sp.speaker: 3 courtier
sp.l: Come, come,
You're friends. Shake hands I'll give you half a dozen
At the next alehouse, to set all right and straight.
And a new song; a dainty one; here 'tis. A ballad.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.l: O thou art happy that canst read —
I would buy ballads too, had I thy learning.

sp.speaker: 3 Cour.
sp.p: Come, we burn daylight, and the ale may sour. Ex.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Call you these courtiers? They are rude silken clowns;
As course within, as watermen or carmen.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Then look on these: here are of those conditionsEn. carman, and waterman.

sp.speaker: Carman
sp.l: I am much obliged
Sir, by the plenteous favours your humanity
And noble virtue have conferred upon me,
To answer with my service your deservings.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: You speak what I should say. Be therefore pleased
T'unload, and lay the wait of your commands
Upon my care to serve you.

sp.speaker: Carman
sp.l: Still your courtesies,
Like waves of a springtide, o'erflow the banks
Of your abundant store; and from your channel,
Or stream of fair affections, you cast forth
those sweet refreshings on me (That were else
But sterile earth) which cause a gratitude
To grow upon me, humble, yet ambitious
In my devoir, to do you best of service.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: I shall no more extend my utmost labour,
With oar and sail to gain the livelihood
Of wife and children, than to set ashore
You, and your faithful honourers at the haven
Of your best wishes.

sp.speaker: Carman
sp.l: Sir, I am no less
Ambitious, to be made the happy means.
With whip and whistle, to draw up or drive
All your detractors to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: See,
Our noble friend.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: Right happily encountered —
I am the just admirer of your virtues.

sp.p: We are, in all, your servants.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: I was in quest,
Of such elect society, to spend
A dinnertime withal.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: Three are the golden number in a tavern;
And at the next of best, with the best meat,
And wine the house affords (If you so please)
We will be competently merry. I
Have received, lately, letters from beyond seas,
Importing much of the occurrences,
And passages of foreign states. The knowledge
Of all I shall impart to you.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: And I
Have all the new advertisements from both
Our universities, of what has passed
The most remarkably of late.

sp.speaker: Carman
sp.l: And from
The court I have the news at full,
Of all that was observable this progress.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yes sir: they know not there, they have
A new King here at home.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent!
We want but now, the news-collecting gallant
To fetch his dinner, and materials
For his this weeks dispatches.

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.l: I dare think
The meat and news being hot upon the table,
He'll smell his way to't.

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.p: Please you to know yours, sir?

sp.speaker: Sed.
sp.l: It shall be as your servant
Then, to prepare your dinner.

sp.speaker: Watchman ▪
sp.l: Yet 'tis my obedienceEx.

sp.speaker: Per:
sp.p: Are these but labouring men, and tother courtiers?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: 'Tis common here sir, for your watermen
To write most learnedly, when your courtier
Has scarce ability to read.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Before I reign
A month among them, they shall change their notes,
Or I'll ordain a course to change their coats.
I shall have much to do in reformation.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Patience and counsel will go through it sir.

sp.speaker: Per:
sp.l: What if I craved? A counsel from new England?
The old will spare me none.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Is this man mad?
My cure goes fairly on. Do you marvel that
Poor men outshine the courtiers? Look you sir,
A sick-man giving counsel to a physician:
And there's a Puritan tradesman, teaching a
Great traveller to lie: that ballad-woman
Gives light to the most learned antiquary
In all the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: A natural fool, there, giving grave instructionsThose persons pass over the stage in couples, according as he describes them.
T'a lord ambassador . that's a schismatic,
Teaching a scrivener to keep his cares:
A parish clerk, there, gives the rudiments
Of military discipline to a general:
And there's a basket maker confuting Bellarmine.

div.head: Act 4. Se. 9.
div.stage: Ent. Byplay like a statesman. 3. or 4. Projectors with bundles of papers.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: We are sailed, I hope,
Beyond the line of madness. Now sir, see
A statesman studious for the commonwealth,
Solicited by projectors of the country.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Your projects are all good I like them well.
Especially these two; this for th' increase of wool:
And this for the destroying of mice: they're good,
And grounded on great reason. As for yours,
for putting down the infinite use of Jacks,
(Whereby the education of young children,
In turning spits, is greatly hindered)
It may be looked into: and yours against
The multiplicity of pocket-watches,
(Whereby much neighbourly familiarity,
By asking, what d'ye guess it is o'clock ?
Is lost) when every puny clerk can carry
The time oth' day in's breeches; this, and these
Hereafter may be look into: for present;
This for the increase of wool; that is to say,
By flaying of live horses, and new covering them
With sheepskins, I do like exceedingly.
And this for keeping of tame owls in cities,
To kill up rats and mice, whereby all cats
May be destroyed, as an especial means
To prevent witchcraft and contagion.

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.l: Will you honour now,
Be pleased to take into consideration
The poor men's suits for briefs, to get relief
By common charity throughout the kingdom,
Towards recovery of their lost estates.

sp.speaker: Byp:
sp.p: What are they? let me hear.

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.l: First, here's a gamester, that sold house and land,
To the known value of five thousand pounds,
And by misfortune of the dice lost all,
To his extreme undoing; having neither
A wife or child to succour him.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: Alas 'tis lamentable: he deserves much pity.

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.p: Then, here's a bawd, of sixty odd years standing.

sp.speaker: Byp:
sp.p: How old was she when she set up?

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.l: But four
And twenty, my good lord. She was both ware
And merchant; flesh and butcher, (As they say)
For the first twelve years of her housekeeping:
She's now upon fourscore, and has made markets
of twice four thousand choice virginities;
And twice their number of indifferent gear.
(No riff-raff was she ever known to cope for)
Her life is certified here by the justices,
Adjacent to her dwelling —

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.l: Quite trade-fallen, my good lord, now in her dotage;
And desperately undone by riot.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Alas good woman,

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.l: She has consumed in prodigal feasts and fiddlers,
And lavish lendings to debauched comrades,
That sucked her purse, in jewels, plate, and money,
To the full value of six thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: She shall have a collection, and deserves it.

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.l: Then here are divers more,
Of panders, cheaters, house-and highway robbers,
That have got great estates in youth and strength,
And wasted all as fast in wine and harlots.
Till age o'ertook 'em, and disabled them,
For getting more

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: For such the law provides
Relief within those counties, where they practised.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Yes, their law punisheth
The robbed, and not the thief, for surer warning,
And the more safe prevention. I have seen
Folks whipped for losing of their goods and money,
And the pick-pockets cherished.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: The weal public,
As it severely punisheth their neglect,
Undone by fire ruins, shipwreck, and the like,
With whips, with brands, and loss of careless ears,
Imprisonment, banishment, and sometimes death;
And carefully maintaineth houses of correction
For decayed scholars, and maimed soldiers;
So doth it find relief. and almshouses,
For such as lived by rapine and by cozenage.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Still worse and worse! abominable! horrid!

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.l: Yet here is one, my lord, above all the rest,
Whose services have generally been known,
though now he be a spectacle of pity:

sp.speaker: Projector
sp.l: The captain of the cutpurses, my lord;
That was the best at's art that ever was,
Is fallen to great decay, by the dead palsy
In both his hands, and craves a large collection.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You shall not get it him.
Do you provide whips, brands; and ordain death,
For men that suffer under fire, or shipwreck,
The loss of all their honest got wealth:
And find relief for cheaters, bawds, and thieves?
I'll hang ye all.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Let not our ignorance suffer in your wrath,
Before we understand your highness' laws,
We went by custom, and the warrant, which
We had in your late predecessors reign;
But let us know your pleasure, you shall find
The state and commonwealth in all obedient,
To alter custom, law, religion, all,
To be conformable to your commands.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis a fair protestation: and my mercy
Meets your submission. See you merit it
In your conformity.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Great sir we shall.
In sign whereof we lacerate these papers. Letoy, Diana, joyless, appear above.
And lay our necks beneath your kingly feet.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Stand up you have our favour.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And mine too?
Never was such an actor as extempore!

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: You were best to fly out of the window to him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: methinks I am even light enough to do it.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I could find in my heart to quoit thee at him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: So he would catch me in his arms I cared not.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Peace both of you, or you'll spoil all.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Your grace
Abounds — abounds — your grace — I say abounds.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Pox o'your mumbling chops; is your brain dry?
Do you pump?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: He has done much my lord, and may
Hold out a little.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Would you could hold your peace ▪
So long.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Do you sneap me too my lord.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I hope his hotter zeal to's actors
Will drive out my wife's love-heat.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I had
No need to come hither to be sneap.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Heyday! The rest will all be lost, we now give over
The play, and do all by extempore,
For your son's good, to soothe him into's wits.
If you'll mar all, you may. Come nearer coxcomb,
Ha you forgotten (Puppy) my instructions
Touching his subjects, and his marriage?

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: I have all now my lord.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: A voice out of the clouds, that doth applaud
Your highness welcome to your subjects' loves.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: So, now he's in. Sit still, I must go down
And set out things in order. Ex.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: A voice that doth inform me of the tidings
Spread through your kingdom, of your great arrival;
And of the general joy your people bring
To celebrate the welcome of their King. Shouts within.
Hark how the country shouts with joyful votes,
Rending the air with music of their throats.Drum and trumpets
Hark how the soldier, with his martial noise,
Threatens your foes, to fill your crown with joys.
Hark how the city, with loud harmony,Haughtboys.
Chants a free welcome to your majesty.
Hark how the court prepares your grace to meetSoft music.
With solemn music, state and beauty sweet.

div.head: Act 4 sce. 10.
div.stage: The soft music playing. Ent. by two and two, divers courtiers, Martha after them, like a Queen between two boys in robes. Her train born up by Barbara, all the lords kneel, and kiss Perigrine's hand, Martha approaching, be starts back, but is drawn on by Byplay and the doctor. Letoy enters and mingles with the rest, and seems to instruct them all.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: O here's a stately show! look master joyless:
Your daughter in law presented like a Queen
Unto your son, I warrant now he'll love her.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and mistress blaze is made
The mother of her maids, if she have any:
Perhaps the Antipodian court has none.
See, see, with what a majesty he receives 'em.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Health, wealth, and joy our wishes bring,
All in a welcome to our King:
May no delight be found,
Wherewith he be not crowned,
Apollo with the Muses,
Who arts divine infuses,
With their choice chyrlouds deck his head;
Love and the graces make his bed:
And to crown all, let Hymen to his side,
Plant a delicious, chaste, and fruitful bride.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Now sir be happy in a marriage choice,
That shall secure your title of a King.
See sir, your state presents to you the daughter,
The only child and heir apparent of
Our late deposed and deceased sovereign,
Who with his dying breath bequeathed her to you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A crown secures not an unlawful marriage.
I have a wife already.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: No: you had sir,
But she's deceased.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: By sure advertisement; and that her fleeting spirit
Is flown into, and animates this Princess.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Be not slack
T'embrace and kiss her sir. He kisses her and retires.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He kisses sweetly;
And that is more than ere my husband did.
But more belongs then kissing to child-getting;
And he's so like my husband, if you note him,
That I shall but lose time and wishes by him,
No, no, I'll none of him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I'll warrant you he shall fulfil your wishes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O but try him you first: and then tell me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: There's a new way indeed to choose a husband!
Yet 'twere a good one to bar fool getting.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Why do you stand aloof sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Mandivell writes
Of people near the antipodes, called Gadlibriens:
Where on the wedding-night the husband hires
Another man to couple with his bride,
To clear the dangerous passage of a maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: 'Slid he falls back again to Mandevile madness.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She may be of that serpentine generation,
That stings oft times to death (As Mandevile writes)

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: She's no Gadlibrien, sir, upon my knowledge.
You may as safely lodge with her, as with
A maid of our own nation. Besides,
You shall have ample counsel: for the present,
Receive her, and entreat her to your chapel.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: For safety of your kingdom, you must do it. Haughtboies exit in state as Letoy directs. Manet Letoy.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: So, so, so, so, this yet may prove a cure.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: See my lord now is acting by himself.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And Letoy's wit cried up triumphant ho.
Come master joyless and your wife, come down
Quickly, your parts are next, I had almost
Forgotten to send my chaplain after them.
You dominae where are you?

div.head: Act. 4. Sce. 11.
div.stage: Enter quail-pipe in a fantastical shape.

sp.speaker: Chap.
sp.l: 'Tis for my part my lord,
Which is not all performed.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: It is sir, and the play for this time. We
Have other work in hand.

sp.speaker: Quai.
sp.l: Then have you lost
Action (I dare be bold to speak it) that
Most of my coat could hardly imitate.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Go shift your coat sir, or for expedition,
Cover it with your own, due to your function.
Follies, as well as vices, may be hid so:
Your virtue is the same; dispatch, and do
As doctor Hughball shall direct you, go.
Now master joyless, do you note the progress
And the fair issue likely to ensue
In your sons cure? observe the doctor's art.
First, he has shifted your sons known disease
Of madness into folly; and has wrought him
As far short of a competent reason, as
He was of late beyond it, as a man
Infected by some foul disease is drawn
By physic into an anatomy,
Before flesh fit for health can grow to rear him,
So is a madman made a fool, before
art can take hold of him to wind him up
Into his proper centre, or the medium
From which he flew beyond himself. The doctor
Assures me now, by what he has collected
As well from learned authors as his practice,
That his much troubled and confused brain
Will by the real knowledge of a woman,
Now opportunely ta'en, be by degrees
Settled and rectified, with the helps beside
Of rest and diet, which he'll administer.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: But 'tis the real knowledge of the woman
(Carnal I think you mean) that carries it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Nay right or wrong, I could even wish
If he were not my husband's son, the doctor
Had made myself his recipe, to be the means
Of such a cure.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Perhaps that course might cure your madness too ▪
Of jealousy, and set all right on all sides.
Sure, if I could but make him such a fool,
He would forgo his madness, and be brought
To christian sense again.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Heaven grant me patience,
And send us to my country home again.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Besides, the young man's wife's as mad as he,
What wise work will they make!

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: The better, fear't not,
Bab blaze shall give her counsel; and the youth
Will give her royal satisfaction,
Now, in this kingly humour, I have a way
To cure your husband's jealousy myself.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Then I am friends again: even now I was not
When you sneaped me my lord.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: That you must pardon:
Come Mr. joyless. The new married pair
Are towards bed by this time ▪ we'll not trouble them
But keep a house-side to ourselves. Your lodging
Is decently appointed.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Sure your lordship
Means not to make your house our prison.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: By
my lordship but I will for this one night.
See sir, the keys are in my hand. You're up,
As I am true Letoy. Consider, sir,
The strict necessity that ties you to't,
As you expect a cure upon your son —
Come lady, see your chamber.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I do wait
Upon your lordship.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: I both wait, and watch,
Never was man so mastered by his match. Ex. omn.

div.head: Act 5. Scene 1.
div.stage: Joyless: with a light in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Diana! ho! where are you? she is lost.
Here is no further passage. All's made fast.
This was the bawdy way, by which she scaped
My narrow watching. Have you privy posterns
Behind the hangings in your stranger's chambers?
She's lost from me, for ever. Why then seek I?
O my dull eyes, to let her slip so from ye,
To let her have her lustful will upon me!
Is this the hospitality of lords?
Why, rather, if he did intend my shame,
And her dishonour, did he not betray me
From her out of his house, to travail in
The bare suspicion of their filthiness;
But hold me a nose-witness to its rankness?
No: this is sure the lordlier way; and makes
The act more glorious in my sufferings. O —
May my hot curses on their melting pleasures,
Cement them so together in their lust,
That they may never part, but grow one monster.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Good gentleman! he is at his prayers now,
for his mad sons good nightwork with his bride.
Well fare your heart sir; you have prayed to purpose;
But not all night I hope. Yet sure he has,
He looks so wild for lack of sleep. You're happy sir.
Your prayers are heard, no doubt, for I'm persuaded
You have a child got you tonight .

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Is't gone
So far do you think?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I cannot say how far ▪
Not fathom deep I think. But to the scantling
Of a child-getting, I dare well imagine.
For which, as you have prayed, forget not sir
To thank the lord oth' house.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: For getting me
A child? why I am none of his great lordship's tenants,
Nor of his followers, to keep his bastards.
Pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I should go tell my lord
The news: he longs to know how things do pass.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Tell him I take it well; and thank him.
I did before despair of children I.
But I'll go wi'ye, and thank him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sure his joy
Has madded him: here's more work for the doctor.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: But tell me first: were you their bawd that speak this?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: What mean you with that dagger?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Nothing I,
But play with't. Did you see the passages
Of things? I ask, were you their bawd?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Their bawd?
I trust she is no bawd, that sees, and helps
(If need require) an ignorant lawful pair
To do their best.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Lord's actions all are lawful.
And how? and how?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: These old folks love to hear.
I'll tell you sir — and yet I will not neither.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: On? they were off sir yet;
And yet a good while after. They were both
So simple, that they knew not what, not how.
For she's sir, a pure maid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I'll speak no more, less you can look more tamely.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Go bring me to 'em then. Bawd will you go?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ah —

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: What ail you sir: why bawd? whose bawd is she?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Your lords bawd, and my wives.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: You are jealous mad.
Suppose your wife be missing at your chamber,
And my lord too at his, they may be honest:
If not, what's that to her, or you I pray,
Here in my lords own house?

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: She has not seen them. I heard all your talk.
The child she intimated, is your grandchild
In posse sir, and of your son's begetting.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, I'll be sworn I meant, and said so too?

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I can give no account,
If she be with my lord I dare not trouble hem.
Nor must you offer at it: no nor stab yourself. Byp. takes away his dagger.
But come with me: we counsel, or, at least,
Govern you better: she may be, perhaps,
About the bride-chamber, to hear some sport;
For you can make her none; alas good old man.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Unless
The killing of yourself may do't; and that
I would forbear, because perhaps 'twould please her.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: If fire, or water, poison, cord, or steel,
Or any means be found to do it: I'll do it;
Not to please her, but rid me of my torment. Ex. joy, and Byp.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: I have more care and charge of you than so.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What an old desperate man is this, to make
Away yourself for fear of being a cuckold!
If every man that is, or that but knows
Himself to be oth' order, should do so,
How many desolate widows would here be,
They are not all of that mind. Here's my husband.

div.head: Act 5. Scene 4.
div.stage: Ent. blaze with a habit in his hand.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Look well. How thinkst thou Tony?
Hast not thou neither slept tonight ?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes, yes.
I lay with the butler. Who was thy bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You know I was appointed to sit up.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes, with the doctor in the bride-chamber.
But had you two no waggery? Ha!

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Nay facks I am not jealous ▪
Thou knowest I was cured long since, and how.
I jealous! I an ass. A man shall n't ask
His wife shortly, how such a gentleman does?
Or how such a gentleman did? or which did best?
But she must think him jealous.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You need not: for
If I were now to die on't, nor the doctor,
Nor I came in a bed tonight : I mean
Within a bed.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Within, or without, or over, or under,
I have no time to think of such poor things.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: O ho Bab.
This is a shape.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A shape? what shape I prithee Tony?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Thou'lt see me in't anon; but shalt not know me
From the stark'st fool ith' town. And I must dance
Naked in't Bab.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Yes Bab. My lord gave order for't last night.
It should ha' been ith' play: but because that
Was broke off, he will have't today.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O Tony.
I did not see thee act ith' play.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: O, but
I did though Bab, two mutes.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Fie fool, thou understandest not what a mute is.
A mute is a dumb speaker in the play.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Dumb speaker! that's a bull. Thou wert the bull
Then, in the play. Would I had seen thee roar.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: That's a bull too, as wise as you are Bab.
A mute is one that acteth speakingly,
and yet says nothing. I did two of them.
The sage man-midwife, and the basketmaker.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well Tony, I will see thee in this thing.
And 'tis a pretty thing.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Prithee good Bab,
Come in, and help me on with't in our tiring-house.
And help the gentlemen, my fellow dancers,
And thou shalt then see all our things, and all
Our properties and practice to the music.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: O Tony come, I long to be at that. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My lord, your strength and violence prevail not.
There is a providence above my virtue,
That guards me from the fury of your lust.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yet, yet, I prithee yield. Is it my person
That thou despisest? See, here's wealthy treasure,A table set forth, covered with treasure.
Jewels, that Cleopatra would have left
Her Marcus for.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My lord 'tis possible,
That she who leaves a husband, may be bought
Out of a second friendship.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Had stout Tarquin
Made such an offer, he had done no rape,
For Lucrece had consented, saved her own,
And all those lives that followed in her cause.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Yet then she had been a loser.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Wouldst have gold?
Mammon, nor Pluto's self should overbid me,
For I'd give all. First, let me rain a shower,
To outvie that which overwhelmed Danae;
And after that another; a full river
Shall from my chests perpetually flow
Into thy store.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I have not much loved wealth,
But have not loathed the sight of it, till now,
That you have soiled it with that foul opinion
Of being the price of virtue. Though the metal
Be pure, and innocent in itself; such use
Of it is odious, indeed damnable,
both to the seller, and the purchaser:
Pity it should be so abused. It bears
A stamp upon't, which but to clip is treason.
'Tis ill used there, where law the life controls;
Worse, where 'tis made a salary for souls.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Deniest thou wealth? wilt thou have pleasure then
Given, and taken freely, without all condition?
I'll give thee such, as shall (If not exceed)
Be at the least, comparative with those,
Which Jupiter got the demigods with; and
Juno was mad she missed.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: My lord, you may
Gloze o'er and gild the vice, which you call pleasure,
With god like attributes; when it is, at best
A sensuality, so far below
Dishonourable, that it is mere beastly;
Which reason ought to abhor; and I detest it,
More than your former hated offers.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Lastly.
Wilt thou have honour! I'll come closer to thee;
(For now the flames of love grow higher in me,
And I must perish in them, or enjoy thee)
Suppose I find by power, or law, or both,
A means to make thee mine, by freeing
Thee from thy present husband.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Hold, stay there.
Now should I utter volumes of persuasions;
Lay the whole world of riches, pleasures, honours,
Before me in full grant, that one, last word
Husband, and from your own mouth spoke, confutes
And vilifies even all. The very name
Of husband, rightly weighed, and well remembered,
Without more law or discipline, is enough
To govern womankind in due obedience;
Master all loose affections, and remove
Those idols, which too much, too many love;
And you have set before me, to beguile
Me of the faith I owe him. But, remember
You grant I have a husband; urge no more,
I seek his love. 'tis fit he loves no whore.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: This is not yet the way. You have seen lady,
My ardent love, which you do seem too slight,
Though to my death, pretending zeal to your husband.
My person, nor my proffers are so despicable,
But that they might (Had I not vowed affection
Entirely to yourself) have met with th'embraces
Of greater persons, no less fair, that can
Too, (If they please) put on formality,
And talk in as divine a strain, as you.
This is not earnest, make my word but good,
Now with a smile, I'll give thee a thousand pound.
Look of my face — come — prithee look and laugh not —
Yes, laugh, and dar'st — dimple this cheek a little;
I'll nip it else.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I pray forbear my lord:
I'm past a child, and will be made no wanton.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: How can this be? so young? so vigorous?
And so devoted to an old man's bed!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: That is already answered. He's my husband.
You are old too my lord.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes, but of better metal:
A jealous old man too, whose disposition
Of injury to beauty, and young blood,
Cannot but kindle fire of just revenge
In you, if you be woman, to requite
With your own pleasure his unnatural spite.
You cannot be worse to him than he thinks you,
Considering all the open scorns and jeers
You cast upon him, to a flat defiance;
Then the affronts I gave, to choke his anger:
And lastly your stolen absence from his chamber:
All which confirms (We have as good as told him)
That he's a cuckold, yet you trifle time,
As 'twere not worth the doing.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Are you a lord?
Dare you boast honour, and be so ignoble?
Did not you warrant me upon that pawn
(Which can take up no money) your blank honour,
That you would cure his jealousy, which affects him
Like a sharp sore, if I to ripen it
would set that counterfeit face of scorn upon him,
Only in show of disobedience, which
You won me to, upon your protestation,
To render me unstained to his opinion,
And quit me of his jealousy for ever.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: No: not unstained by your leave, if you call
Unchastity a stain. But for his yellows,
Let me but lie with you, and let him know it,
His jealousy is gone, all doubts are cleared,
And for his love and good opinion,
He shall not dare deny't. Come; be wise,
And this is all: all is as good as done
To him already: let't be so with us;
And trust to me, my power, and your own,
To make all good with him — if not: now mark,
To be revenged for my lost hopes (Which yet
I pray thee save) I'll put thee in his hands,
Now in his heat of fury; and not spare
To boast thou art my prostitute; and thrust ye
Out of my gates, to try't out by yourselves.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: This you may do, and yet be still a lord;
This can I bear, and still be the same woman!
I am not troubled now, your wooing oratory,
Your violent hands (Made stronger by your lust)
Your tempting gifts, and larger promises
Of honour and advancements were all frivolous;
But this last way of threats, ridiculous,
To a safe mind, that bears no guilty grudge:
My peace dwells here, while yonder sits my judge.
And in that faith I'll die.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: She is invincible!
Come I'll relate you to your husband.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: No,
I'll meet her with more joy than I received
Upon our marriage-day. My better soul.
Let me again embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Take your dudgeon sir,
I ha' done you simple service.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: O my lord,
My lord, you have cured my jealousy, I thank you;
And more, your man for the discovery;
But most the constant means, my virtuous wife,
your medicine my sweet lord.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: She has ta'en all
I mean to give her sir now sirrah, speak.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I brought you to the stand from whence you saw
How the game went.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: I seemed to do it against my will, by which I gained
Your bribe of twenty pieces.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: But I assure you, my lord give me order,
To place you there, after it seems he had
Well put her to't within.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Stay, stay, stay, stay;
Why may not this be then a counterfeit action,
Or a false mist to blind me with more error?
The ill I feared may have been done before,
And all this but deceit to daub it o'er.

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.p: I must take charge I see o'th' dagger again.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Come joyless, I have pity on thee; hear me.
I swear upon mine honour she is chaste.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I prithee hear me.
I tried and tempted her for mine own ends,
More than for thine.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And had she yielded, I not only had
Rejected her (For it was never my purpose,
(Heaven I call thee to witness) to commit
A sin with her) but laid a punishment
Upon her, greater than thou couldst inflict.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Do you know your father lady?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I hope I am so wise a child.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Go call
In my friend Truelocke,

sp.speaker: Byp.
sp.l: Take your dagger sir,
Now I dare trust you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Sirrah, dare you fool.
When I am serious? send in master Truelocke. Exit Byp.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Sir, I am neither conjurer nor witch,
But a great fortune-teller, that you'll find,
You are happy in a wife sir, happier — yes
Happier by a hundred thousand pound,
Than you were yesterday —

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I mean in possibilities: provided that
You use her well, and never more be jealous.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Look you this way sir,
When I speak to you, I'll cross your fortune else,
As I am true Letoy.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Mad, mad, he's mad,
Would we were quickly out on's fingers yet.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: When saw you your wife's father? answer me?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: He came for London four days before us.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: 'Tis possible he's here then, do you know him

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: O I am happy in his sight. Dear sir. Enter Truelocke. she kneels.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: 'Tis but so much knee-labour lost, stand up,
Stand up, and mind me.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: You are well met, son joyless.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: How have you been concealed, and this house?
Here's mystery in this.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Know sir, that i sent for him, and for you,
Instructing your friend blaze my instrument,
To draw you to my doctor with your son,
Your wife i knew must follow, what my end
Was in't shall quickly be discovered to you,
In a few words, of your supposed father.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Yes, come master Truelocke,
My constant friend of thirty years acquaintance,
Freely declare with your best knowledge now,
Whose child this is.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Your honour does as freely
Release me of my vow, then in the secret
I locked up in this breast these seventeen years
Since she was three days old.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: True, master Truelocke,
I do release you of your vow: now speak.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Now she is yours my lord; your only daughter,
And know you master joyless, for some reason
Known to my lord; and large reward to me,
She has been from the third day of her life
Reputed mine; and that so covertly,
That not her lady mother, nor my wife
Knew to their deaths, the change of my dead infant,
Nor this sweet lady ▪ 'tis most true we had
A trusty nurse's help and secrecy,
Well paid for, in the carriage of our plot.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Now shall you know what moved me sir. I was
A thing beyond a madman, like yourself,
jealous; and had that strong distrust, and fancied
Such proofs unto myself against my wife,
That I conceived the child was not mine own,
And scorned to father it; yet I gave to breed her
And marry her as the daughter of this gentleman
(Two thousand pound I guess you had with her)
But since your match, my wife upon her deathbed,
So cleared herself of all my foul suspicions,
(Blessed be her memory) that i then resolved
By some quaint way (For i am still Letoy)
To see and try her thoroughly; and so much
To make her mine, as I should find her worthy.
And now thou art my daughter, and mine heir.
Provided still (For I am still Letoy)
You honourably love her, and defy
The cuckold-making fiend foul jealousy.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: My lord, 'tis not her birth and fortune, which
Do jointly claim a privilege to live
Above my reach of jealousy, shall restrain
That passion in me, but her well tried virtue:
In the true faith of which i am confirmed,
And thoroughly cured.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: As i am true Letoy
Well said. I hope thy son is cured by this too.
Now mistress blaze! here is a woman now!
I cured her husband's jealousy, and twenty more
Ith'town, by means I and my doctor wrought.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Truly my lord, my husband has ta'en bread
And drunk upon't, that under heaven he thinks,
You were the means to make me an honest woman,
Or (At the least) him a contented man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, I believe you have done
And if your husband, lady, be cured, as he should be;
And as all foolish jealous husbands ought to be,
I know what was done first, if my lord took
That course with you as me —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My lord to tell you, (As the doctor tells me)
The bride and bridegroom, both, are coming on,
the sweetliest to their wits again.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Now you are a happy man sir; and I hope a quiet man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Content! So was my husband, when he knew
The worst he could by his wife. Now you'll live quiet lady.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Why fliest thou off, thus woman, from the subject
Thou wert upon?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I beg your honour's pardon.
And now I'll tell you. Be it by skill or chance,
Or both, was never such a cure, as is
Upon that couple: now they strive which most
Shall love the other.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Up! up, and ready to lie down again:
There is no ho with them;
They have been in th' antipodes to some purpose;
And, now, are risen, and returned themselves:
He's her dear per, and she is his sweet Mat.
His kingship and her queenship are forgotten.
And all their melancholy and his travails past,
And but supposed their dreams.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now sir, the doctor, (For he is become
An utter stranger to your son; and so
Are all about 'em) craves your presence,
And such as he's acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Go sir.
And go you daughter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Daughter! that's the true trick of all old whoremasters, to call their wenches daughters.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Has he known you friend Trulock too?

sp.speaker: Let
sp.p: Go, then, and possess him (Now, he is sensible) how things have gone; what art, what means, what friends have been employed in his rare cure; and win him, by degrees, to sense of where he is; bring him to me; and I have yet an entertainment for him, of better settle-brain, than drunkard's porridge, to set him right. As I am true Letoy, I have one toy left. Go, and go you, why stay'st thou? Exe. Joy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If I had been a gentlewoman born,
I should have been your daughter too my lord.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: But never as she is.
You'll know anon.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Neat city-wives flesh, yet may be as good,
As your course country gentlewoman's blood. Exit Bar.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Go with thy flesh to turn-bull shambles? Ho
Within there.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: The music, songs,
And dance I gave command for, are they ready?

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: All my good lord: and (In good sooth) I cannot enough applaud your honours quaint conceit in the design; so apt, so regular, so pregnant, so acute, and so (Withal) poetice legitimate, as I may say justly with Plautus —

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Prithee say no more, but see upon my signal given, they act as well as I designed.

sp.speaker: Qua.
sp.p: Nay not so well my exact lord, but as they may, they shall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: I know no flatterer in my house but this,
But for his custom I must bear with him.
'Sprecious they come already. Now begin.

div.head: Act 5. Sce. 9.
div.stage: A solemn lesson upon the recorders. Ent. Truelocke, joyless and Diana, Peregrine and Martha, doctor, and Barbara, Letoy meets them. Truelocke presents Peregrine and Martha to him, he salutes them. They seem to make some short discourse. Then Letoy appoints them to sit Peregrine seems something amazed. The music ceases.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Again you are welcome sir and welcome all.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am what you are pleased to make me; but withal, so ignorant of mine own condition; whether I sleep, or wake, or talk, or dream; whether I be, or be not; or if I am, whether I do, or do not any thing: for I have had (If I now wake) such dreams, and been so far transported in a long and tedious voyage of sleep, that I may fear my manners can acquire no welcome, where men understand themselves.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: This is music, sir, you are welcome; and I give full power unto your father, and my daughter here, your mother to make you welcome. Joyless whispers Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: My lord you'll put him back again, if you trouble his brain with new discoveries.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Fetch him you on again then: pray are you Letoy or I?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I fear your show will but perplex him too.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I care not sir, I'll have it to delay your cure a while, that he recover soundly. Come sit again, again you are most welcome.

div.head: Act 5. Sce. 10.
div.stage: A most untunable flourish. Ent. discord attended by Folly, jealousy, melancholy and madness.

sp.p: There's an unwelcome guest; uncivil discord that trains into my house her followers, folly, and jealousy, melancholy, and madness.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: My husband presents jealousy in the black and yellow jaundied suit there, half like man, and tother half like woman with one horn, and ass-ear upon his head.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Peace woman, mark what they do: but but by the way, conceive me this, but show sir, and devise.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: How goes he back again, now doctor? sheugh.

lg.head: Discord. Song in untunable notes.
lg.l: Come forth my darlings, you that breed
The common strifes that discord feed:
Come in the first place, my dear folly;
Jealousy next, then melancholy.
And last come madness, thou art he
That bearest th' effects of all those three,
Lend me your aids, so discord shake you crown,
And make this place a kingdom of our own.

div.head: Act 5. Scene 11.
div.stage: They dance. After a while they are broke off by a flourish, and the approach of harmony followed by Mercury, Cupid, Bacchus and Apollo. Discord and her faction fall down.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: See harmony approaches, leading on,
'Gainst discords factions fear great deities;
Mercury, Cupid, Bacchus, and Apollo.
Wit against folly, love against jealousy,
Wine against melancholy, and 'gainst madness, health.
Observe the matter and the method.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: And how upon the approach of harmony,
Discord and her disorders are confounded.

lg.head: Harmony. Song.
lg.l: Come wit, come love, come wine, come health,
Maintainers of my commonwealth,
'Tis you make harmony complete,
And from the spheres (Her proper seat)
You give her power to reign on earth,
where discord claims a right by birth.
Then let us revel it while we are here,
And keep possession of this hemisphere.

div.stage: After a strain or two, discord cheers up her faction. They all rise, and mingle in the dance with harmony and the rest. Dance.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Note there how discord cheers up her disorders,
To mingle in defiance with the virtues:
But soon they vanish; and the mansion quitEx discord.
Unto the gods of health, love, wine and wit,
Who triumph in their habitation new,
Which they have taken, and assign to you;
In which they now salute you — bids you beSalute Exe.
Of cheer; and for it, lays the charge on me.
And unto me you're welcome, welcome all.
Meat, wine, and mirth shall flow, and what I see,
Yet wanting in your cure, supplied shall be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And so shall I,
After a few such nights more.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Are you there?
Good madam, pardon errors of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: I am too happy made to think of wrong.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: We will want nothing for you that may please,
Though we dive for it toth' antipodes.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Whither my cure be perfect yet or no,
It lies not in my doctorship to know.
Your approbation may more raise the man,
Than all the college of physicians can;
And more health from your fair hands may be won,
Then by the streakings of the seventh son.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And from our travails in th' antipodes.
We are not yet arrived from off the seas:
But on the waves of desperate fears we roam
Until your gentler hands do waft us home.

div.p: You shall find in this book more than was presented upon the stage, and left out of the presentation, for superfluous length (As some of the players pretended) I thought good all should be inserted according to the allowed original; and as it was, at first, intended for the cockpit stage, in the right of my most deserving friend Mr. William Beeston, unto whom it properly appertained; and so i leave it to thy perusal, as it was generally applauded, and well acted at Salisbury court.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
